('50', 1, 7, 17, 1840) 5. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('50', 1, 8, 18, 1862) YERAVDA MANDIR, August 24, 1930
('50', 1, 9, 19, 1894) MIRA, I have your love letter written during your journey to Madras.
('50', 1, 9, 20, 1963) I am hoping that this strain will not prove too much for you.
('50', 1, 9, 21, 2025) Your descriptions are all valuable.
('50', 1, 9, 22, 2061) Yes, I had a strenuous time during the Nehrus’ visit.
('50', 1, 9, 23, 2115) It was with difficulty that I was able to spin 375 rounds without doing which I should feel most unhappy.
('50', 1, 9, 24, 2221) The box wheel is working very well and undoubtedly causes less strain.
('50', 1, 9, 25, 2292) It gives more satisfactory work now that I have put on it the thin mal you sent me.
('50', 1, 9, 26, 2376) The thick mal was causing trouble.
('50', 1, 9, 27, 2411) The carding bow is working to perfection.
('50', 1, 9, 28, 2453) It imposes no strain on me.
('50', 1, 9, 29, 2481) Kakasaheb rolls the slivers.
('50', 1, 9, 30, 2510) He has yet to learn carding which he proposes to begin shortly.
('50', 1, 9, 31, 2574) The translation of the bhajans continues as before regularly but slowly
('50', 2, 0, 1, 2646) VOL.50: 23 AUGUST, 1930 5 JANUARY, 1931 3
('50', 2, 1, 2, 2688) and I see no immediate chance of greater output.
('50', 2, 1, 3, 2737) I am keeping well.
('50', 2, 1, 4, 2756) The weight fluctuates.
('50', 2, 1, 5, 2779) Last week I regained one pound out of two or three I seemed to have lost.
('50', 2, 1, 6, 2853) There has been no loss of energy.
('50', 2, 1, 7, 2887) The water here is hard and therefore constipation requires a little handling.
('50', 2, 1, 8, 2965) BAPU [PS.] You will be glad to know that the tant has not once broken.

('50', 4, 1, 2, 5192) 10. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('50', 4, 2, 3, 5222) YERAVDA MANDIR, August 24/26, 1930
('50', 4, 3, 4, 5257) NARANDAS, This time I got the letters earlier than usual, that is, on Wednesday instead of on Thursday.
('50', 4, 3, 5, 5361) Among the letters is one for Satis Babu.
('50', 4, 3, 6, 5402) He is Krishnadas’s guru, Satis Mukherjee.
('50', 4, 3, 7, 5444) His address is Harra Road, Calcutta.
('50', 4, 3, 8, 5481) I have forgotten the number of the flat.
('50', 4, 3, 9, 5522) You will find it somewhere in my papers.
('50', 4, 3, 10, 5563) Surendra is likely to know it.
('50', 4, 3, 11, 5594) Or you will get it in the Ashram office itself.
('50', 4, 3, 12, 5642) How is Devdas’s health?
('50', 4, 3, 13, 5666) Tell him that I often think of him.
('50', 4, 3, 14, 5702) Has Ramdas’s health recovered?
('50', 4, 3, 15, 5733) I have before now asked for the names of those who have been released.
('50', 4, 3, 16, 5804) It would be better if against each name the quantity of carding and spinning done by the person is also mentioned.
('50', 4, 3, 17, 5919) If, when you do not get a cloth lined envelope, the ordinary envelope is tightly secured by a string, like a packet sent as book post, there will be no risk afterwards.
('50', 4, 3, 18, 6088) Keshu seems to have lost health again.Take immediate and effective measures to help him to recover.
('50', 4, 3, 19, 6188) Giriraj’s illness has lasted quite long.
('50', 4, 3, 20, 6229) His blood must be impure.
('50', 4, 3, 21, 6255) I have not received the guide to Singer’s.
('50', 4, 3, 22, 6298) If you find it difficult to secure a copy, give up the attempt.
('50', 4, 3, 23, 6362) I understand what you write about Hasmukhrai.
('50', 4, 3, 24, 6408) Give him the letters if and when you think you may.
('50', 4, 3, 25, 6460) Read the letter to Zaulinger before giving it to her.
('50', 4, 3, 26, 6514) Hence I don’t write about her in this letter.
('50', 4, 3, 27, 6560) You must have sent an acknowledgment to Dhangopal.
('50', 4, 3, 28, 6611) How is Jamnadas?
('50', 4, 3, 29, 6628) Do the authorities let you visit him occasionally?
('50', 4, 4, 30, 6679) Tuesday morning, August 26, 1930
('50', 4, 5, 31, 6712) Non possession is allied to non stealing.
('50', 4, 5, 32, 6754) A thing not originally stolen must nevertheless be classified as stolen property if we possess it without needing it.
('50', 4, 5, 33, 6872) Possession implies provision for the future.
('50', 4, 5, 34, 6917) A seeker after truth, a follower of the law of love, cannot hold anything against tomorrow.
('50', 4, 5, 35, 7009) God never stores for the morrow; He never creates more than what is strictly needed for the moment.
('50', 4, 5, 36, 7109) If, therefore, we repose faith in His providence, we should be assured that He will give us every day our daily bread, meaning everything we require.
('50', 4, 5, 37, 7259) Saints and men of faith have always found justification for it from their experience.
('50', 4, 5, 38, 7345) Our ignorance or negligence of the Divine Law, which gives to man from day to day his daily bread and no more, has given
('50', 5, 0, 1, 7466) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('50', 5, 1, 2, 7506) rise to inequalities with all the miseries attendant upon them.
('50', 5, 1, 3, 7570) The rich have a superfluous store of things which they do not need, and which are therefore neglected and wasted; while millions starve to death for want of sustenance.
('50', 5, 1, 4, 7739) If each retained possession only of what he needed, no one would be in want and all would live in contentment.
('50', 5, 1, 5, 7850) As it is, the rich are discontented no less than the poor.
('50', 5, 1, 6, 7909) The poor man would fain become a millionaire, and the millionaire a multi millionaire.
('50', 5, 1, 7, 7996) The poor are not content if they get their daily needs.
('50', 5, 1, 8, 8052) They have a right, however, to get enough for their daily needs and it is the duty of society to help them to satisfy them.
('50', 5, 1, 9, 8176) The rich should take the initiative in dispossession with a view to universal diffusion of the spirit of contentment.
('50', 5, 1, 10, 8294) If only they keep their own property within moderate limits, the starving will be easily fed and will learn the lesson of contentment along with the rich.
('50', 5, 1, 11, 8449) Perfect fulfilment of the ideal of non possession requires that man should, like the birds, have no roof over his head, no clothing and no stock of food for the morrow.
('50', 5, 1, 12, 8618) He will indeed need his daily bread, but it will be God’s business, and not his, to provide it.
('50', 5, 1, 13, 8714) Only very very few, if any at all, can reach this ideal.
('50', 5, 1, 14, 8771) We ordinary seekers may not be repelled by the seeming impossibility.
('50', 5, 1, 15, 8841) But we must keep the ideal constantly before us, and in the light thereof critically examine our possessions and try to reduce them.
('50', 5, 1, 16, 8974) Civilization, in the real sense of the term, consists not in the multiplication, but in the deliberate and voluntary reduction of wants.
('50', 5, 1, 17, 9111) This alone promotes real happiness and contentment and increases the capacity for service.
('50', 5, 1, 18, 9202) Judging by this criterion, we find that in the Ashram we possess many things the necessity for which cannot be proved, and we thus tempt our neighbours to steal.
('50', 5, 1, 19, 9364) If people try, they can reduce their wants and, as the latter diminish, they become happier, more peaceful and healthier.
('50', 5, 1, 20, 9486) From the standpoint of pure truth, the body, too, is a possession.
('50', 5, 1, 21, 9553) It has been truly said that desire for enjoyment creates bodies for the soul and sustains them.
('50', 5, 1, 22, 9649) When this desire vanishes, there remains no further need for the body and man is free from the vicious cycle of births and deaths.
('50', 5, 1, 23, 9780) The soul is omnipresent; why should she care to be confined within the cage like body, or do evil and even kill for the sake of that cage?
('50', 5, 1, 24, 9919) We thus arrive at the ideal of total renunciation and learn the use of the body for the purposes of service so long as it exists, so much so that service, and not bread, becomes for us the staff of life.
('50', 5, 1, 25, 10123) We eat and drink, sleep and wake, for service
('50', 6, 0, 1, 10169) VOL.50: 23 AUGUST, 1930 5 JANUARY, 1931 7
('50', 6, 1, 2, 10211) Such an attitude of mind brings us real happiness and the beatific vision in the fulness of time.
('50', 6, 1, 3, 10309) Let us all examine ourselves from this standpoint.
('50', 6, 1, 4, 10360) We should remember that non possession is a principle applicable to thoughts as well as to things.
('50', 6, 1, 5, 10459) A man who fills his brain with useless knowledge violates that inestimable principle.
('50', 6, 1, 6, 10545) Thoughts which turn us away from God or do not turn us towards Him are unnecessary possessions and constitute impediments in our way.
('50', 6, 1, 7, 10679) In this connection we may consider the definition of knowledge contained in Chapter XIII of the Gita.
('50', 6, 1, 8, 10781) We are there told that humility, amanitvam, etc., constitute knowledge and that all the rest is ignorance.
('50', 6, 1, 9, 10888) If this is true—and there is no doubt that it is true—much that we hug today as knowledge is ignorance pure and simple, and therefore only does us harm instead of conferring any benefit.
('50', 6, 1, 10, 11075) It makes the mind wander and even reduces it to a vacuity, and discontent flourishes in endless ramifications of evil.
('50', 6, 1, 11, 11194) Needless to say, this is not a plea for inertia.
('50', 6, 1, 12, 11243) Every moment of our life should be filled with mental or physical activity, but that activity should be sattvik, tending towards truth.
('50', 6, 1, 13, 11379) One who has consecrated his life to service cannot be idle for a single moment.
('50', 6, 1, 14, 11459) But we have to learn to distinguish between good activity and evil activity.
('50', 6, 1, 15, 11536) This discernment goes naturally with a single minded devotion to service.
('50', 6, 1, 16, 11610) Blessings from BAPU [PS.] Kakasaheb’s weight has again increased by one pound, and his cheerfulness has also increased.
('50', 6, 1, 17, 11730) I have regained one pound from what I had lost.
('50', 6, 1, 18, 11778) For the past three days, I have been taking boiled vegetables in addition to curds.
('50', 6, 1, 19, 11862) You will see that today’s letters are put into one of the envelopes received from you, fresh slips of paper being pasted on it.
('50', 6, 1, 20, 11990) You can use the envelope again.
('50', 6, 1, 21, 12022) BAPU [PPS.] There are 53 letters.
('50', 6, 2, 22, 12056) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M.U./I

('50', 7, 1, 2, 12139) 11. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK
('50', 7, 2, 3, 12170) YERAVDA MANDIR, August 29, 1930
('50', 7, 3, 4, 12202) PREMA, I got your letter.
('50', 7, 3, 5, 12228) No one should be amused at my writing on slips of paper or be angry with me for that reason.
('50', 7, 3, 6, 12321) That is the proper thing for me to do.
('50', 7, 3, 7, 12360) Though I write on such slips, I try to make each letter as interesting as I can in the time I get.
('50', 7, 3, 8, 12459) Why are you alarmed by the suspicion that you have got some disease in your body?
('50', 7, 3, 9, 12541) What would it matter even if you had a disease and that too a grave one?
('50', 7, 3, 10, 12614) “The body may live or perish, what should endure is one’s devotion to God.’’ 1 We have learnt at least this in the Ashram, if nothing more.
('50', 7, 3, 11, 12754) If you fast for a few days, the body will be cleansed.
('50', 7, 3, 12, 12809) You require Kuhne baths, hip baths and particularly friction sitz baths.
('50', 7, 3, 13, 12882) If you do not know about them, ask Kanta or Radha.
('50', 7, 3, 14, 12933) I think they know.
('50', 7, 3, 15, 12952) You may also read about them in Kuhne’s book.
('50', 7, 3, 16, 12998) Whenever women suffer from any disease, it becomes necessary to know the facts about their monthly periods.
('50', 7, 3, 17, 13106) Are they normal with you?
('50', 7, 3, 18, 13132) Are they regular in appearance and duration?
('50', 7, 3, 19, 13177) Are they painful?
('50', 7, 3, 20, 13195) If necessary, consult a doctor.
('50', 7, 3, 21, 13227) I have not read Arvind Babu’s book.
('50', 7, 3, 22, 13263) I alone know how limited is my reading.
('50', 7, 3, 23, 13303) My main interest is in reading the book of nature.
('50', 7, 3, 24, 13354) I shall never finish reading it.
('50', 7, 3, 25, 13387) You should have enough sleep.
('50', 7, 3, 26, 13417) You should observe the rule of sleeping from 9 to 4. Blessings from BAPU
('50', 7, 4, 27, 13490) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 10232; also C.W. 6680. Courtesy: Premabehn Kantak

('50', 19, 0, 1, 29444) 20 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('50', 19, 1, 2, 29485) FEARLESSNESS.
('50', 19, 1, 3, 29499) As every reader of the Gita knows fearlessness heads the list of the divine attributes enumerated in Chapter XVI.
('50', 19, 1, 4, 29613) Whether this is merely due to the exigencies of metre or whether the pride of place has been deliberately yielded to fearlessness, is more than I can say.
('50', 19, 1, 5, 29768) In my opinion, however, fearlessness richly deserves the first rank assigned to it.
('50', 19, 1, 6, 29852) For it is indispensable for the growth of the other noble qualities.
('50', 19, 1, 7, 29921) How can one seek Truth or cherish love without fearlessness?
('50', 19, 1, 8, 29982) As Pritam says: “The path of Hari is the path of the brave, not of cowards.” Hari here means Truth.
('50', 19, 1, 9, 30082) And the brave are those armed with fearlessness, not with the sword, the rifle and the like.
('50', 19, 1, 10, 30175) These are taken up only by those who are possessed by fear.
('50', 19, 1, 11, 30235) Fearlessness connotes freedom from all external fear, fear of disease, bodily injury and death, of dispossession, of losing one’s nearest and dearest, of losing reputation or giving offence, and so on.
('50', 19, 1, 12, 30437) One who overcomes the fear of death does not surmount all other fears, as is commonly but erroneously supposed.
('50', 19, 1, 13, 30549) Some of us do notfear death, but flee from the minor ills of life.
('50', 19, 1, 14, 30616) Some are ready to die themselves, but cannot bear their loved ones being taken away from them.
('50', 19, 1, 15, 30711) Some misers will put up with all this, will part even with theirlives, but not their property; others will do any number of black deeds in order to uphold their supposed prestige.
('50', 19, 1, 16, 30891) Some will swerve from the straight and narrow path which lies clear before them, simply because they are afraid of incurring the world’s odium.
('50', 19, 1, 17, 31035) The seeker after Truth must conquer all these fears.
('50', 19, 1, 18, 31088) He should be ready to sacrifice his all in the quest of Truth, even as Harishchandra did.
('50', 19, 1, 19, 31178) The story of Harishchandra may be only a parable; but every seeker will bear witness to its truth from his personal experience and, therefore, that story is as precious as any historical fact.
('50', 19, 1, 20, 31371) Perfect fearlessness is almost impossible to cultivate.
('50', 19, 1, 21, 31427) It can be attained only by him who has realized the Supreme, as it implies freedom from delusion.
('50', 19, 1, 22, 31525) One can always progress towards this goal by determined and constant endeavour and by cultivating self confidence As I have stated at the very outset, we must give up all external fears.
('50', 19, 1, 23, 31712) But the internal foes we must always fear.
('50', 19, 1, 24, 31755) We are rightly afraid of animal passion, anger and the like.
('50', 19, 1, 25, 31816) External fears cease of their own accord when once we have conquered these traitors within the camp.
('50', 19, 1, 26, 31917) All such fears revolve round the body as the centre, and will therefore disappear as soon as we get rid of attachment for the body.
('50', 19, 1, 27, 32049) We thus find that all external fear is the baseless fabric of our own
('50', 20, 0, 1, 32119) VOL.50: 23 AUGUST, 1930 5 JANUARY, 1931 21
('50', 20, 1, 2, 32162) vision.
('50', 20, 1, 3, 32170) Fear has no place in our hearts when we have shaken off attachment for wealth, for family and for the body.
('50', 20, 1, 4, 32278) “Enjoy the things of the earth by renouncing them’’ 1 is the sovereign precept.
('50', 20, 1, 5, 32358) Wealth, family and the body will be there just the same; we have only to change our attitude towards them.
('50', 20, 1, 6, 32465) All these are not ours, but God’s.
('50', 20, 1, 7, 32500) Nothing whatever in this world is ours.
('50', 20, 1, 8, 32540) Even we ourselves are His.
('50', 20, 1, 9, 32567) Why then should we entertain any fear?
('50', 20, 1, 10, 32606) The Upanishad, therefore, directs us to give up attachment for things while we enjoy them.
('50', 20, 1, 11, 32697) That is to say, we must be interested in them not as proprietors but only as trustees.
('50', 20, 1, 12, 32784) He on whose behalf we hold them will give us the strength and the weapons requisite for defending them against all usurpers.
('50', 20, 1, 13, 32909) When we thus cease to be masters and reduce ourselves to the rank of servants, humbler than the very dust under our feet, all fears will roll away like mists; we shall attain ineffable peace and see Satyanarayana, the God of Truth, face to face.
('50', 20, 1, 14, 33155) Kakasaheb had not so far taken a categorical vow of spinning; he has done so now.
('50', 20, 1, 15, 33237) The vow is that he will spin for not less than two hours and not less than 160 yards daily.
('50', 20, 1, 16, 33329) He has also started carding.
('50', 20, 1, 17, 33358) He spends most of his time in physical activities.

('50', 22, 1, 2, 35478) 33. STATEMENT TO T. B. SAPRU AND M. R. JAYAKAR 1
('50', 22, 2, 3, 35527) September 5, 1930
('50', 22, 3, 4, 35545) DEAR FRIENDS, We have very carefully gone through the letter, written to you by H. E. the Viceroy, dated 28 8 1930. You have kindly supplemented it with a record of your conversations with the Viceroy on points not covered by the letter.
('50', 22, 3, 5, 35783) We have equally carefully gone through the Note signed by Pandit Motilal Nehru, Dr. Syed Mahmud and Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, and sent by them through you.
('50', 22, 3, 6, 35938) This note embodies their considered opinion on the said letter and the conversation.
('50', 22, 3, 7, 36023) We gave two anxious nights to these papers and we had the benefit of a full and free discussion with you on all the points arising out of these papers.
('50', 22, 3, 8, 36175) And as we have told you, we have all arrived at the definite conclusion that we see no meeting ground between the Government and the Indian National Congress so far as we can speak for the latter, being out of touch with the outside world.
('50', 22, 3, 9, 36415) We unreservedly associate ourselves with the opinion contained in the Note sent by the distinguished prisoners in the Naini Central Prison, but these friends expect us to give in our own words our view of the position finally reached in the negotiations for peace, which you, with patriotic motives, have carried on during the past two months at considerable sacrifice of your own time and no less inconvenience to yourselves.
('50', 22, 3, 10, 36842) We shall therefore allude as briefly as possible to the fundamental difficulties that have stood in the way of peace being achieved.
('50', 22, 4, 11, 36975) 1 After meeting Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru and M. R. Jayakar the Viceroy addressed a letter to Sapru on August 28, vide Appendix Viceroy’s letter to Sir T.B. Sapru”, 28 8 1930. Sapru and Jayakar then met Motilal Nehru, Jawaharlal Nehru and Dr. Syed Mahmud at Naini Jail on August 30 and 31 and showed them the Viceroy’s letter as also notes of conversation with him, vide Appendix “Notes of Conversations with Viceroy’s”, 5 9 1930. The Nehrus then gave them their final note addressed to Gandhiji, vide Appendix “Note From Nehrus”, 31 8 1930..
('50', 22, 4, 12, 37514) With these documents Sapru and Jayakar saw Gandhiji and other leaders at Yeravda Jail on September 3, 4 and 5. A draft of this Statement available in Gandhiji’s hand in S.N. 1927 bears some changes and additions in a handwriting other than Gandhiji’s.
('50', 23, 0, 1, 37766) 24 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('50', 23, 1, 2, 37807) The Viceroy’s letter, dated July 16, 1930, is, we have taken, intended to satisfy, so far as may be, the terms of the interview Pandit Motilal Nehru gave to Mr. George Slocombe on June 20th, and the statement submitted by Mr. Slocombe to him on June 25, and approved by him.
('50', 23, 1, 3, 38082) We are unable to read in the Viceroy’s language in his letter of July 16 anything like satisfaction of the terms of the interview or the said statement.
('50', 23, 1, 4, 38235) Here are the relevant parts of the interview and the statement.
('50', 23, 2, 5, 38299) In the interview it was stated: “If the terms of the Round Table Conference are to be left open and we are expected to go to London to argue the case for Dominion Status, I should decline.
('50', 23, 2, 6, 38488) If it was made clear, however, that the Conference would meet to frame a constitution for a Free India subject to such adjustments of our mutual relations as are required by the special needs and conditions of India and our past association, I for one would be disposed to recommend to the Congress to accept the invitation to participate in the Conference.
('50', 23, 2, 7, 38846) We must be masters in our household, but we are ready to agree to reasonable terms for the period of transfer of power from a British administration in India to a responsible Indian Government.
('50', 23, 2, 8, 39040) The Conference must be to meet British people to discuss these terms as nation to nation and on an equal footing.’’ 1
('50', 23, 3, 9, 39158) The statement contained the following:
('50', 23, 4, 10, 39197) “The Government would give private assurance that they would support the demand for full responsible Government for India subject to such mutual adjustments and terms of transfer as are required by the special needs and conditions of India and by her long association with Great Britain and as may be decided by the Round Table Conference.” 2
('50', 23, 5, 11, 39540) Here is the relevant part of the Viceroy’s letter:
('50', 23, 6, 12, 39591) It remains my earnest desire, as it is that of my Government—and I have no doubt also that of His Majesty’s Government—to do everything we can in our respective spheres to assist the people of India to obtain as large a degree of management of their own affairs as can be shown to be consistent with making provision for those matters in regard to which they are not at present in a position to assume responsibility.
('50', 23, 6, 13, 40009) What those matters may be, and what provisions may best be made for them, will engage the attention of the Conference, but I have never believed that, with

('50', 24, 2, 3, 40373) We feel that there is a vast difference between the two positions.
('50', 24, 2, 4, 40440) Where Pandit Motilalji visualizes a Free India enjoying a status different in kind from the present as a result of the deliberations of the proposed Round Table Conference, the Viceroy’s letter merely 2
('50', 24, 3, 5, 40643) commits him and his Government and the British Cabinet to an earnest desire 3 to assist the people of 4 India to obtain 5 as large a degree of the management of their 6 own affairs as can be shown 7 to be consistent with making provision for those matters in regard to which they are not at present in a position to assume responsibility.

('50', 24, 3, 7, 41178) As we had the fear that our interpretation was correct in our letter of 15 8 1930 signed also by Pandit Motilal Nehru, Dr. Syed Mahmud and Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, we put our position negatively and said what would not in our opinion satisfy the Congress.
('50', 24, 3, 8, 41434) The letter you have now brought from H.E. the Viceroy reiterates the original position taken up by him in his first letter, and, we are grieved to say, contemptuously dismisses our letter as unworthy of consider ation and regards discussion on the basis of the proposals contained in the letter as impossible.
('50', 24, 3, 9, 41744) You have thrown further light on the question by telling us that “if Mr. Gandhi definitely faced the Government of India with such a question”, i.e., the right of secession from the Empire at India’s will, the Viceroy would say, that “they were not prepared to treat it as an open question”.
('50', 24, 3, 10, 42036) We, on the other hand regard the question as the central point in any constitution that India is to secure and one which ought not to need any argument.

('50', 25, 0, 1, 42652) 26 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('50', 25, 1, 2, 42693) Responsible Government or full Self Government or whatever other term it is to be known by, it can be only on an absolutely voluntary basis, leaving each party to sever the partnership or association at will.
('50', 25, 1, 3, 42902) If India is to remain no longer a part of the Empire but is to become an equal and free partner in the Commonwealth, she must feel the want and warmth of that association and never otherwise.
('50', 25, 1, 4, 43094) You will please observe this position is clearly brought out in the interview already alluded to by us.
('50', 25, 1, 5, 43198) So long, therefore, as the British Government or the British people regard this position as impossible or untenable, the Congress must, in our opinion, continue the fight for freedom.
('50', 25, 1, 6, 43382) The attitude taken up by the Viceroy over the very mild proposal made by us regarding the salt tax affords a further painful insight into the Government’s mentality.
('50', 25, 1, 7, 43548) It is as plain as daylight to us that, from the dizzy heights of Simla, the rulers of India are unable to understand or appreciate the difficulties of the starving millions living in the plains whose incessant toil makes 1 Government from such a giddy height at all possible.
('50', 25, 1, 8, 43824) If the blood of innocent people spilt during the past five months to sustain the monopoly of a gift of nature 2 next in importance to poor people only to air and water has not brought home to the Government the conviction of its utter immorality, no Conference of Indian leaders as suggested by the Viceroy can possibly do so.
('50', 25, 1, 9, 44151) The suggestion that those who ask for the repeal of the monopoly should show a source of equivalent revenue adds insult to injury.
('50', 25, 1, 10, 44282) This attitude is an indication that if Government can help it the existing crushingly expensive system shall continue to the end of time.
('50', 25, 1, 11, 44420) We venture further to point out that not only does the Government here, but Governments all the world over, openly condone breaches of measures which have become unpopular but which for technical or other reasons cannot straightway be repealed.
('50', 25, 1, 12, 44665) We need not now deal with many other important matters in which too there is no adequate 3 advance from the Viceroy to the popular position set forth by us.
('50', 25, 1, 13, 44822) We hope we have brought out sufficient weighty matters in which there appears at present to be an unbridgeable gulf between the British Government and the Congress.
('50', 25, 2, 14, 44987) 1 The draft here reads: “starving millions living in the plains of India who make”.

('50', 25, 2, 16, 45138) 3 Added in the draft
('50', 26, 0, 1, 45159) VOL.50: 23 AUGUST, 1930 5 JANUARY, 1931 27
('50', 26, 1, 2, 45202) There need, however, be no disappointment for the apparent failure of the peace negotiations.
('50', 26, 1, 3, 45296) The Congress is engaged in a grim struggle for freedom.
('50', 26, 1, 4, 45352) The nation has resorted to a weapon which the rulers being unused to it will take time to understand and appreciate.
('50', 26, 1, 5, 45469) We are not surprised that a few months’ suffering has not converted them 1. The Congress desires to harm no 2 single legitimate interest by whomsoever acquired.
('50', 26, 1, 6, 45630) It has no quarrel with Englishmen as such, but it resents and will resent with all the moral strength at its command the intolerable British domination.
('50', 26, 1, 7, 45783) Non violence being assured to the end, we are certain of the early fulfilment of the national aspiration.
('50', 26, 1, 8, 45889) This we say in spite of the bitter and often insulting language used by the powers that be in regard to Civil Disobedience.
('50', 26, 1, 9, 46013) Lastly, we once more thank you for the great pains you have taken to bring about peace, but we suggest that the time has not arri ved when any further peace negotiations should be carried on with those in charge of the Congress organization.
('50', 26, 1, 10, 46255) As prisoners, we labour under an obvious 3 handicap.
('50', 26, 1, 11, 46308) Our opinion is based, as it must be, on second hand evidence and runs the risk of being faulty.

('50', 30, 1, 2, 51210) 40. LETTER TO BECHARDAS DOSHI
('50', 30, 2, 3, 51240) September 6, 1930
('50', 30, 3, 4, 51258) BHAI BECHARDAS, I have your letter.
('50', 30, 3, 5, 51294) Really speaking Kakasaheb should reply to it.
('50', 30, 3, 6, 51340) But just now I reply as he can write only a limited number of letters.
('50', 30, 3, 7, 51411) Take it that the view expressed here is that of us both.
('50', 30, 3, 8, 51468) I will say nothing about the method of giving the etymology 1. If Kakasaheb wishes, he will write about it later.
('50', 30, 3, 9, 51582) After discussing the matter with him, I understand that your main work is to translate the Agamas 2. Shri Punjabhai has given the money for that work, and it is our duty, therefore, to carry out the object of the grant as quickly as possible.
('50', 30, 3, 10, 51825) You should not mind it if in devoting your time to that work you have to postpone or delay work on etymology; or you may get it done through somebody else if that can be conveniently arranged.
('50', 30, 3, 11, 52018) The idea in placing Bhakti Prasad at your disposal was not that he might do original work on his own, but that he might work under you and help you, and might, if he was persevering, acquire proficiency in the work.
('50', 30, 3, 12, 52234) As for your eyes I think you should lay down a limit.
('50', 30, 3, 13, 52288) You should be satisfied with whatever help is available in Gujarat.
('50', 30, 3, 14, 52356) Dr. Haribhai is a specialist in eye diseases.
('50', 30, 3, 15, 52402) If he cannot help you, you should assume that nobody else will be able to and rest content.
('50', 30, 3, 16, 52494) There should be a self imposed limit like this for anyone who has decided to live a simple life.
('50', 30, 3, 17, 52591) Do the countless poor have the benefit of help even from a Dr. Haribhai?
('50', 30, 3, 18, 52664) This of course is my personal view.
('50', 30, 3, 19, 52700) I can say that Kakasaheb now agrees with this view.
('50', 30, 3, 20, 52752) But this is a delicate matter.
('50', 30, 3, 21, 52783) Everyone should lay down the limit for himself according to his own lights and his own wish.
('50', 30, 3, 22, 52876) The limits accepted by one person cannot, in such a matter, apply to all.
('50', 30, 3, 23, 52950) BAPU [PS.] My reason for using “now” and saying that “Kakasaheb now agrees” is that, as he tells me, he himself had formerly advised you to consult one or two other doctors.
('50', 30, 3, 24, 53124) He now thinks that my view is right.

('50', 30, 5, 26, 53205) 1 In the Gujarati dictionary under preparation then in the Gujarat Vidyapith 2 Jain scriptures.

('50', 32, 1, 2, 54836) My mastery over the wheel is increasing.
('50', 32, 1, 3, 54877) The fatigue is no longer felt.
('50', 32, 1, 4, 54908) I see that if you concentrate on the puni end whilst the thread is drawing, then on the point of the spindle when the thread is being shifted to the cone and then on the cone when it is brought there, you avoid breakage if the puni is sound.

('50', 32, 1, 18, 55807) The spindle is mounted on it and the thread is held between the left hand fingers.
('50', 32, 1, 19, 55890) The result is that it winds tightly on the winder.
('50', 32, 1, 20, 55941) There is saving in time too.

('50', 39, 5, 10, 64710) 57. LETTER TO MATHURADAS PURUSHOTTAM
('50', 39, 6, 11, 64747) YERAVDA MANDIR, September 8, 1930
('50', 39, 7, 12, 64781) MATHURADAS, I have your letter, but see none from Motibehn.
('50', 39, 7, 13, 64841) In regard to degrees, after discussing the matter Kakasaheb and I have both come to the conclusion that there should not be more than three stages and that for each stage the name of the diploma or the degree should be the same for all subjects, whether craft or industry or art or letters or philosophy.
('50', 39, 7, 14, 65146) At present there are three diplomas or degrees, Vineet, Visharad and Pundit, in the Vidyapith.
('50', 39, 7, 15, 65241) Vineet (Matriculation, Entrance) is one who has acquired general knowledge in a subject.
('50', 39, 7, 16, 65330) Visharad (Graduate) is one who has acquired proficiency in his subject to the extent of being able to teach it to others also.
('50', 39, 7, 17, 65457) And Pundit is one who can do research in the subject and write dissertations and articles concerning it.
('50', 39, 7, 18, 65562) Having regard to this, we should for the present, award the degree of Pundit to no one, we may award the diploma of Dhanur Vineet or of Dhanur Visharad.
('50', 39, 7, 19, 65715) If you award the degrees or diplomas, see that you do not make them cheap.
('50', 39, 7, 20, 65790) Appoint examiners and give the degree or the diploma only to those who pass according to a prescribed standard.
('50', 39, 7, 21, 65902) Blessings from BAPU From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 3744

('50', 40, 2, 3, 66039) September 5/9, 1930

('50', 40, 5, 28, 67504) Tuesday morning, September 9, 1930
('50', 40, 6, 29, 67539) REMOVAL OF UNTOUCHABILITY
('50', 40, 7, 30, 67565) This, too, is a new observance, like control of the palate, and may even appear a little strange.
('50', 40, 7, 31, 67663) But it is of vital importance.
('50', 40, 7, 32, 67694) Untouchability means pollution by the touch of certain persons by reason of their birth in a particular caste or family.
('50', 40, 7, 33, 67815) In the words of Akha, it is an excrescence.
('50', 40, 7, 34, 67859) In the guise of religion, it is always in the way and corrupts religion.
('50', 40, 7, 35, 67932) None can be born untouchable as all are sparks of one and the same Fire.
('50', 40, 7, 36, 68005) It is wrong to treat certain human beings as untouchables from birth.
('50', 40, 7, 37, 68075) It is also wrong to entertain false
('50', 41, 0, 1, 68111) 42 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('50', 41, 1, 2, 68152) scruples about touching a dead body, which should be an object of compassion and respect.
('50', 41, 1, 3, 68242) It is only out of considerations of health that we bathe after touching a dead body or after an application of oil, or after a shave.
('50', 41, 1, 4, 68376) A man who does not bathe in such cases may be looked upon as dirty, but surely not as a sinner.
('50', 41, 1, 5, 68472) A mother may be “untouchable” so long as she has not bathed or washed her hands and feet after cleaning up her child’s dirt, but if a child happened to touch her, it would not be polluted by the touch.
('50', 41, 1, 6, 68674) But Bhangis, Dheds, Chamars and the like are contemptuously looked down upon as untouchables from birth.
('50', 41, 1, 7, 68779) They may bathe for years with any amount of soap, dress well and wear the marks of Vaishnavas, read the Gita every day and follow a learned profession, and yet they remainun touchables!
('50', 41, 1, 8, 68965) This is rank irreligion fit only to be destroyed.
('50', 41, 1, 9, 69015) By treating removal of untouchability as an Ashram observance, we assert our belief that untouchability is not only not a part and parcel of Hinduism, but that it is a plague, which it is the bounden duty of every Hindu to combat.
('50', 41, 1, 10, 69246) Every Hindu, therefore, who considers it a sin should atone for it by fraternizing with untouchables, associating with them in a spirit of love and service, deeming himself purified by such acts, redressing their grievances, helping them patiently to overcome ignorance and other evils due to the slavery of ages, and inspiring other Hindus to do likewise.
('50', 41, 1, 11, 69603) When one visualizes the removal of untouchability from this spiritual standpoint, its material and political results sink into insignificance and we befriend the so called untouchables regardless of such results.
('50', 41, 1, 12, 69816) Seekers after Truth will never waste a thought on the material consequences of their quest, which is not a matter of policy with them, but something interwoven with the very texture of their lives.
('50', 41, 1, 13, 70014) Similar is the case of those who have vowed to remove untouchability.
('50', 41, 1, 14, 70084) When we have realized the supreme importance of this observance, we shall discover that the evil it seeks to combat is not restricted in its operation to the suppressed classes.
('50', 41, 1, 15, 70262) Evil, no bigger than a mustard seed in the first instance, soon assumes gigantic proportions and in the long run destroys that upon which it settles.
('50', 41, 1, 16, 70412) Thus this evil has now assailed all departments of life.
('50', 41, 1, 17, 70469) We practise untouchability against followers of other religions than our own, against those who belong to other sects than our own within the Hindu fold and even against members of our own sect, so much so that, ever busy observing untouchability, we .become a burden on the earth.
('50', 41, 1, 18, 70751) We have hardly enough time even to look after ourselves,.
('50', 41, 1, 19, 70809) thanks to the never ending ablutions and exclusive preparation of food necessitated by false notions of untouchability.
('50', 41, 1, 20, 70929) While pretending to pray to God, we offer worship not to God but to ourselves.
('50', 41, 1, 21, 71008) This observance, therefore, is not fulfilled merely by our making friends
('50', 42, 0, 1, 71082) VOL.50: 23 AUGUST, 1930 5 JANUARY, 1931 43
('50', 42, 1, 2, 71125) with untouchables but by loving all life as our own selves.
('50', 42, 1, 3, 71185) Removal of untouchability means love for and service of the whole world and thus merges into ahimsa.
('50', 42, 1, 4, 71286) Removal of untouchability spells the breaking down of barriers between man and man, and between the various orders of beings.
('50', 42, 1, 5, 71412) We find such barriers erected everywhere in the world; but here we have been mainly concerned with the untouchability which has received religious sanction in India and reduced lakhs and crores of human beings to a state bordering on slavery.
('50', 42, 1, 6, 71655) Blessings from BAPU PS.
('50', 42, 1, 7, 71679) One Kantu Gajiwala is a resident of Surat and lives in Khapatia Chakla.

('50', 57, 2, 16, 95714) Tuesday morning, September 16, 1930 I read in papers about Ba having been harassed in Surat by the police.
('50', 57, 2, 17, 95821) Is there any truth in the report?
('50', 57, 2, 18, 95855) The law, that to live man must work, first came home to me upon reading Tolstoy’s writings on bread labour.
('50', 57, 2, 19, 95963) But even before that I had begun to pay homage to it after reading Ruskin’s Unto This Last.
('50', 57, 2, 20, 96055) The phrase ‘jatmahenat’ is a translation of the English expression ‘bread labour’.
('50', 57, 2, 21, 96138) Literally it means labour for roti.
('50', 57, 2, 22, 96174) The divine law that man must earn his bread by labouring with his own hands was first stressed, not by Tolstoy but by an obscure Russian writer named T. M. Bondoref.
('50', 57, 2, 23, 96340) Tolstoy took it from him and gave it wider publicity when he accepted it.
('50', 57, 2, 24, 96414) In my view, the same principle has been set forth in Chapter III of the Gita where we are told that he who eats without offering sacrifice eats stolen food.
('50', 57, 2, 25, 96571) Sacrifice here can only mean bread labour.
('50', 57, 2, 26, 96614) Be that as it may, that verse is the origin of our observance.
('50', 57, 2, 27, 96677) Reason, too, leads us to an identical conclusion.
('50', 57, 2, 28, 96727) How can a man who does not do body labour have the right to eat?
('50', 57, 2, 29, 96792) “In the sweat of thy brow shalt thou eat thy bread,” says the Bible.
('50', 57, 2, 30, 96861) A millionaire cannot carry on for long, and will soon get tired of his life, if he rolls in his bed all day long and is even helped to his food.
('50', 57, 2, 31, 97006) He, therefore, induces hunger by exercise and helps himself to the food he eats.
('50', 57, 2, 32, 97087) If everyone, whether rich or poor, has thus to take exercise in some
('50', 58, 0, 1, 97156) VOL.50: 23 AUGUST, 1930 5 JANUARY, 1931 59
('50', 58, 1, 2, 97199) shape or form, why should it not assume the form of productive labour, i.e., bread labour?
('50', 58, 1, 3, 97290) No one asks the cultivator to inhale fresh air, or to use his muscles.
('50', 58, 1, 4, 97361) And more than nine tenths of humanity lives by tilling the soil.
('50', 58, 1, 5, 97426) How much happier, healthier and more peaceful would the world become if the remaining tenth followed the example of the overwhelming majority at least to the extent of labouring enough for their food.
('50', 58, 1, 6, 97627) And many hardships connected with agriculture would be easily redressed if such people took a hand in it.
('50', 58, 1, 7, 97733) Again, invidious distinctions of rank would be abolished if everyone without exception acknowledged the obligation of bread labour.
('50', 58, 1, 8, 97865) At present these distinctions have invaded even the varna system in which there was not a trace of it originally.
('50', 58, 1, 9, 97979) There is a world wide conflict between capital and labour, and the poor envy the rich.
('50', 58, 1, 10, 98066) If all worked for their bread, distinctions of rank would be obliterated; the rich would still be there, but they would deem themselves only trustees of their property and would use it mainly in the public interest.
('50', 58, 1, 11, 98282) Bread labour is a veritable blessing to one who would observe non violence, worship Truth and make the observance of brahmacharya a natural act.
('50', 58, 1, 12, 98427) This labour can truly be related to agriculture alone.
('50', 58, 1, 13, 98482) But at present at any rate everybody is not in a position to take to it.
('50', 58, 1, 14, 98555) A person can, therefore, spin or weave, or take up carpentry or smithery, instead of tilling the soil, always regarding agriculture, however, to be the ideal.
('50', 58, 1, 15, 98714) Everyone must be his own scavenger.
('50', 58, 1, 16, 98750) Evacuation is as necessary as eating; and the best thing would be for everyone to dispose of his own waste.
('50', 58, 1, 17, 98858) If this is impossible, each family should see to its own scavenging.
('50', 58, 1, 18, 98927) I have felt for years that there must be something radically wrong where scavenging has been made the concern of a separate class in society.
('50', 58, 1, 19, 99069) We have no historical record of the man who first assigned the lowest status to this essential sanitary service.
('50', 58, 1, 20, 99182) Whoever he was, he did us no good.
('50', 58, 1, 21, 99217) We should, from our very childhood, have the idea impressed upon our minds that we are all scavengers, and the easiest way of doing so is for everyone who has realized this to commence bread labour as a scavenger.
('50', 58, 1, 22, 99431) Scavenging, thus intelligently taken up, will help one to understand religion in a different and truer light.
('50', 58, 1, 23, 99541) If children, the old and those disabled by illness do not do bread labour, that should not be regarded as violation of the law of bread labour.

('50', 64, 0, 1, 105444) VOL.50: 23 AUGUST, 1930 5 JANUARY, 1931 65
('50', 64, 1, 2, 105487) 93. LETTER TO R. V. MARTIN
('50', 64, 2, 3, 105514) YERAVDA CENTRAL PRISON, September 21, 1930
('50', 64, 3, 4, 105557) DEAR MAJOR MARTIN,
('50', 64, 4, 5, 105576) I must now unburden myself of my second difficulty.
('50', 64, 4, 6, 105628) I do not doubt a word of what you have told me about the charges of alleged ill treatment in this prison.
('50', 64, 4, 7, 105734) Yet I cannot dispel from my mind all the reports that have appeared in the Press.
('50', 64, 4, 8, 105816) The writers could not have deliberately lied about everything.
('50', 64, 4, 9, 105879) I am sure that some of the statements are gross exaggerations.
('50', 64, 4, 10, 105942) I hope that most are, and I should like to believe that all are false.
('50', 64, 4, 11, 106013) But my mind is disturbed.
('50', 64, 4, 12, 106039) There may be things you do not know; there must be things which you look at from one angle and the prisoners concerned from another.
('50', 64, 4, 13, 106172) My duty in the circumstances seems to be plain.
('50', 64, 4, 14, 106220) I must ask to be allowed to see them occasionally, if I may not be permitted to live with them.
('50', 64, 4, 15, 106316) I have told you I desire no privileges.
('50', 64, 4, 16, 106356) What comforts are allowed to me may be taken away from me.
('50', 64, 4, 17, 106415) If I am isolated for the sake of the comforts, they mean little to me, whereas isolation means everything to me.
('50', 64, 4, 18, 106528) I desire no comforts that may not be allowed to the other prisoners suffering from the same physical disabilities as I. I do not believe in classification which, in my opinion, is degrading.
('50', 64, 4, 19, 106719) If I permit myself comforts which the other prisoners like me do not enjoy, I do so because of my physical needs 1. But I would fain sacrifice health if it has to be purchased by the sacrifice of the privilege of serving my companions, many of whom I know and none of whom I consider to be in any way inferior to me.
('50', 64, 4, 20, 107036) I was able to bear the separation so long as I was under the impression that all was well.
('50', 64, 4, 21, 107127) But the knowledge that young Ratilal is no more, that Pyarelal who is like a son to me has been suffering, that the elderly Narsinhabhai was near death’s door and the persistent complaints in the Press have awakened me to a sense of my duty, viz., that I should strive to the utmost of my ability to establish touch with them.
('50', 64, 5, 22, 107454) 1 From the draft available in S.N. 19980. In the source the word is obli terated.
('50', 65, 0, 1, 107536) 66 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('50', 65, 1, 2, 107577) I know that it is not in your or the I. G. P.’s power to grant me the permission requested.
('50', 65, 1, 3, 107669) I would therefore ask you please to place this letter before the Government and secure an early reply.
('50', 65, 1, 4, 107772) I am aware as prisoner I have no rights and no choice as to the disposal of my body.
('50', 65, 1, 5, 107857) But I know also that the upkeep of my body requires my co operation.
('50', 65, 1, 6, 107926) I should no longer be interested [in] the preservation of a body that cannot be used for the service that the dweller within yearns after.
('50', 65, 1, 7, 108065) I am human.
('50', 65, 1, 8, 108077) Even as a prisoner I cannot divest myself of the human in me.
('50', 65, 1, 9, 108139) I need not give the assurance, perhaps you will be able to give it, if any be required, that my presence among my companions will not be used to subvert discipline but on the contrary, it is highly likely to promote it.
('50', 65, 1, 10, 108359) The moral code of a civil resister requires him willingly to submit to all prison discipline that is not in conflict with self respect.
('50', 65, 1, 11, 108495) Lastly I would like to draw the Government’s attention to the fact that when a somewhat similar incident occurred in 1923 in this very prison, I was allowed to see two prisoners with the result that what promised to be a grave tragedy was averted.
('50', 65, 1, 12, 108743) 1 The present Inspector General of Police is aware of the facts of the case.
('50', 65, 1, 13, 108820) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('50', 65, 2, 14, 108850) From a photostat: G.N. 3852; also Bombay Secret Abstract, 750(5)/A, p.
('50', 65, 3, 15, 108921) 94. LETTER TO LILAVATI ASAR
('50', 65, 4, 16, 108949) September 21, 1930
('50', 65, 5, 17, 108968) LILAVATI, I got your letter.
('50', 65, 5, 18, 108997) If you do not become impatient, you are bound to get the strength to put your ideals into practice.
('50', 65, 5, 19, 109097) As we get indigestion if we start eating all at once, so also we fail in our attempt if we try to put anything in practice without first judging our capacity and this gives rise to despair.
('50', 65, 5, 20, 109287) If we ourselves cannot judge our capacity we should follow the advice of some person in whose judgment we have faith and who has given the advice after considering our capacity.
('50', 65, 5, 21, 109465) It will be enough if, after pouring out your heart before Gangabehn, you do what she asks you to do.

('50', 71, 1, 2, 116135) 105. LETTER TO CHANDRAKANTA
('50', 71, 2, 3, 116163) September 21, 1930
('50', 71, 3, 4, 116182) KANTA, I have your letter.
('50', 71, 3, 5, 116209) It is well that you have sought our Kamalabehn’s 1 company.

('50', 71, 3, 10, 116558) Soda neutralizes the acid in the curd.

('50', 71, 6, 15, 116821) 106. LETTER TO J. C. KUMARAPPA
('50', 71, 7, 16, 116852) September 22, 1930

('50', 77, 2, 6, 126285) Tuesday morning, September 23, 1930
('50', 77, 3, 7, 126321) EQUALITY OF RELIGIONS.
('50', 77, 3, 8, 126344) This is the new name we have given to the Ashram observance which we know as ‘Tolerance’.
('50', 77, 3, 9, 126434) ‘Sahishnuta’ is a translation of the English word ‘Tolerance’.
('50', 77, 3, 10, 126497) I did not like that word, but could not think of a better one.
('50', 77, 3, 11, 126560) Kakasaheb, too, did not like that word.
('50', 77, 3, 12, 126600) He suggested ‘Respect for all religions’.
('50', 77, 3, 13, 126642) I didn’t like that phrase either.
('50', 77, 3, 14, 126676) Tolerance may imply a gratuitous assumption of the inferiority of other faiths to one’s own and respect suggests a sense of patronizing whereas ahimsa teaches us to entertain the same respect for the religious faiths of others as we accord to our own, thus admitting the imperfection of the latter.
('50', 77, 3, 15, 126975) This admission will be readily made by a seeker of Truth, who follows the law of Love.
('50', 77, 3, 16, 127062) If we had attained the full vision of Truth, we would no longer be mere seekers, but would have become one with God, for Truth is God.
('50', 77, 3, 17, 127197) But being only seekers, we prosecute our quest, and are conscious of our imperfection.
('50', 77, 3, 18, 127284) And if we are imperfect ourselves, religion as conceived by us must also be imperfect.
('50', 77, 3, 19, 127371) We have not realized religion in its perfection, even as we have not realized God.
('50', 77, 3, 20, 127454) Religion of our conception, being thus imperfect, is always subject to a process of evolution and re interpretation.
('50', 77, 3, 21, 127571) Progress towards Truth, towards God, is possible only because of such evolution.
('50', 77, 3, 22, 127652) And if all faiths outlined by men are imperfect, the question of comparative merit does not arise.
('50', 77, 3, 23, 127751) All faiths constitute a revelation of Truth, but all are imperfect and liable to error.
('50', 77, 3, 24, 127839) Reverence for other faiths need not blind us to their faults.
('50', 77, 3, 25, 127901) We must be keenly alive to the defects of our own faith also, yet not leave it on that account, but try to overcome those defects.
('50', 77, 3, 26, 128032) Looking at all religions with an equal eye, we would not only not hesitate, but would think it our duty, to blend into our faith every acceptable feature of other faiths.
('50', 77, 3, 27, 128203) The question then arises: why should there be so many different faiths?
('50', 77, 3, 28, 128275) The soul is one, but the bodies which she animates are many.
('50', 77, 3, 29, 128336) We cannot reduce the number of bodies; yet we recognize the unity of the soul.
('50', 77, 3, 30, 128415) Even as a tree has a single trunk, but many branches and leaves, so is there one true and perfect Religion, but it becomes many as it passes through the human medium.
('50', 78, 0, 1, 128582) VOL.50: 23 AUGUST, 1930 5 JANUARY, 1931 79
('50', 78, 1, 2, 128625) All religions are divinely inspired, but they are imperfect because they are products of the human mind and taught by human beings.
('50', 78, 1, 3, 128757) The one Religion is beyond all speech.
('50', 78, 1, 4, 128796) Imperfect men put it into such language as they can command and their words are interpreted by other men equally imperfect.
('50', 78, 1, 5, 128920) Whose interpretation is to be held to be the right one?
('50', 78, 1, 6, 128976) Everybody is right from his own standpoint, but it is not impossible that everybody may be wrong.
('50', 78, 1, 7, 129074) Hence the necessity for tolerance, which does not mean indifference towards one’s own faith, but a more intelligent and purer love for it.
('50', 78, 1, 8, 129213) Tolerance gives us spiritual insight, which is as far from fanaticism as the north pole is from the south.
('50', 78, 1, 9, 129320) True knowledge of religion breaks down the barriers between faith and faith.
('50', 78, 1, 10, 129397) Cultivation of tolerance for other faiths will impart to us a truer understanding of our own.
('50', 78, 1, 11, 129491) Tolerance obviously does not disturb the distinction between right and wrong, or good and evil.
('50', 78, 1, 12, 129587) The reference here throughout is naturally to the principal faiths of the world.
('50', 78, 1, 13, 129668) They are all based on common fundamentals.
('50', 78, 1, 14, 129711) They have all produced great saints.
('50', 78, 1, 15, 129748) There is some difference between tolerance towards other religions and tolerance towards their followers.
('50', 78, 1, 16, 129854) We should have equal regard for all human beings—for the wicked as for the saintly, for the impious as for the pious—but we should never tolerate irreligion.
('50', 78, 1, 17, 130012) This idea may need elaboration.
('50', 78, 1, 18, 130044) If you do not follow it easily, ask me.
('50', 78, 2, 19, 130084) Blessings from BAPU [PS.] If you have not followed the discourse fully, it would be best not to translate it.
('50', 78, 2, 20, 130194) I will certainly try myself to translate it.

('50', 95, 1, 2, 151228) 147. LETTER TO R. V. MARTIN
('50', 95, 2, 3, 151256) YERAVDA CENTRAL PRISON, September 30, 1930
('50', 95, 3, 4, 151299) DEAR MAJOR MARTIN, It was on 21st instant that I sent you my letter requesting that I should be permitted to establish touch with the civil resistance prisoners in this jail.
('50', 95, 3, 5, 151474) I made the request about seeing my secretary and co worker Pyarelal even earlier.
('50', 95, 3, 6, 151556) I must now press for an early answer.
('50', 95, 3, 7, 151594) I know the Government’s preoccupations and, as a prisoner, I should like to spare them all the trouble l can on my behalf.
('50', 95, 3, 8, 151717) But the request I have made is a peremptory call of my fundamental being.
('50', 95, 3, 9, 151791) I can no longer restrain myself now.
('50', 95, 3, 10, 151828) The deprivation of touch with these fellow prisoners is unbearable for me.
('50', 95, 3, 11, 151903) Unless, therefore, I get satisfaction by Saturday noon next, I must begin to withdraw my co operation as to the upkeep of my body.
('50', 95, 3, 12, 152034) To what extent I shall carry the non co operation, I am unable to say at present.
('50', 95, 3, 13, 152116) It will be determined, as the days proceed, by the inner urge and my courage and strength.
('50', 95, 3, 14, 152207) The commencement will be made with my refusing all food except the ordinary convict diet, i.e., such of it as I can religiously take.
('50', 95, 3, 15, 152341) I can take only five natural ingredients in addition to salt.
('50', 95, 3, 16, 152403) Therefore so far as I can see, I can take only kanji and bajari and juwari chapati.
('50', 95, 3, 17, 152487) I may not take dal or vegetables as they contain more than five ingredients.
('50', 95, 3, 18, 152564) The kanji and chapati I shall take on the responsibility of and at the desire of the authorities.
('50', 95, 3, 19, 152662) I am not sure that after years of abstention from them, my system can cope with either.
('50', 95, 3, 20, 152750) I have arrived at this compromise to start with, because I am anxious to cause as little embarrassment as I can.
('50', 95, 3, 21, 152863) I would like the Government not to regard this letter as a threat but consider it as an act of courtesy and consideration.
('50', 95, 3, 22, 152986) My desire is not to take the Government unawares in any serious steps I may take in order to vindicate what is to me a human right.
('50', 95, 4, 23, 153118) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('50', 95, 5, 24, 153148) From a photostat: G.N. 3853; also Bombay Secret Abstracts, 750(5)/A, p.

('50', 96, 2, 3, 153294) September 25/30, 1930
('50', 96, 3, 4, 153316) NARANDAS, This time I start with your letter.
('50', 96, 3, 5, 153362) Last week I ran short of time and had to be very brief about some points.
('50', 96, 3, 6, 153436) Write and tell me, if you know, all about the persons who live in Rajagopalachari’s Ashram, where Subbiah and his wife are and so on.

('50', 96, 3, 9, 153697) She seems to be a wise and good lady, but she takes time to understand our point of view in everything.
('50', 96, 3, 10, 153801) I don’t see anything wrong in letting her join the night watch, if she feels so inclined.
('50', 96, 3, 11, 153891) Her argument is correct.
('50', 96, 3, 12, 153916) Indian sisters may not be ready to move as freely as she is ready to do; if, however, anyone wishes to join her, she may.
('50', 96, 3, 13, 154038) I have merely expressed a view from here without knowing all the circumstances there.
('50', 96, 3, 14, 154124) Do what you yourself think proper.
('50', 96, 3, 15, 154159) What shall I say about Keshu and others?
('50', 96, 3, 16, 154200) Read the letter which I shall write to them this time and give it to them.
('50', 96, 3, 17, 154275) Keshu is an upright young man.
('50', 96, 3, 18, 154306) He will probably understand his dharma in the course of time, and so I don’t feel like writing anything to him.
('50', 96, 3, 19, 154418) You, for your part, should be bold and tell him what you think right.
('50', 96, 3, 20, 154488) This time, of course, I will write to him.
('50', 96, 3, 21, 154531) My diet consists of three pounds of milk turned into curds and taken at two meals, and milk once.
('50', 96, 3, 22, 154629) Then nine tomatoes, small or big as supplied and the required quantity of boiled vegetables such as cabbage, pumpkin, etc.
('50', 96, 3, 23, 154752) I add salt afterwards if I require.
('50', 96, 3, 24, 154788) I gave up sweet potatoes four days ago.
('50', 96, 3, 25, 154828) Dr. Jivraj visited Kakasaheb and he thought that it would cause constipation.
('50', 96, 3, 26, 154906) I had again found it necessary to take enemas.
('50', 96, 3, 27, 154953) I, therefore, decided to see the effect of giving up sweet potatoes.
('50', 96, 3, 28, 155022) I observe no change.
('50', 96, 3, 29, 155043) If I keep up my strength, I will not resume sweet potatoes.
('50', 96, 3, 30, 155103) I didn’t think they were doing me any harm.
('50', 96, 3, 31, 155147) It is the water of this place which seems to cause constipation to a person of my constitution.
('50', 96, 3, 32, 155243) There is, however, no cause for worry at all.
('50', 96, 3, 33, 155289) I shall be weighed this evening and will mention the weight in this letter.
('50', 96, 3, 34, 155365) Enemas are nothing new to me, but I should certainly like to do without them if possible.
('50', 96, 3, 35, 155455) I wish to carry on without fresh fruit as long as I can.
('50', 96, 3, 36, 155512) If by eating vegetables I do not
('50', 97, 0, 1, 155545) 98 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('50', 97, 1, 2, 155586) succeed in getting rid of enemas and if I feel weak in the slightest degree, I will resume dates and raisins.
('50', 97, 1, 3, 155696) No one should worry on my account.
('50', 97, 1, 4, 155731) My spinning is improving.
('50', 97, 1, 5, 155757) The speed seems to be increasing.
('50', 97, 1, 6, 155791) At any rate, I don’t feel tired now.
('50', 97, 1, 7, 155828) I will not be too eager for the present to increase the output.
('50', 97, 1, 8, 155892) I feel a little unhappy that I have had to abandon the effort to memorize the Gita verses.
('50', 97, 1, 9, 155983) But I am waiting for an opportunity to resume it.
('50', 97, 1, 10, 156033) In the beginning, I used to try to memorize them while spinning.
('50', 97, 1, 11, 156098) But I saw that that interfered with the spinning.
('50', 97, 1, 12, 156148) I realize every day the necessity for ever more concentration for good spinning.
('50', 97, 1, 13, 156229) I see that there is a great difference between mere spinning and the art of spinning.
('50', 97, 1, 14, 156315) I wish to learn the art.
('50', 97, 1, 15, 156340) Maybe I shall not succeed in acquiring it during this life.
('50', 97, 1, 16, 156400) I will be satisfied if I am not slack in my effort.
('50', 97, 1, 17, 156452) I realized that my eagerness to learn the Gita verses by heart while spinning was a sign of my slackness.
('50', 97, 1, 18, 156558) That was against the teaching of the Gita.
('50', 97, 1, 19, 156601) I wish to memorize the Gita verses if I can do that and at the same time acquire proficiency in spinning, but I would be false to the teaching of the Gita as I understand it if I tried to learn its verses by heart at the cost of my spinning.

('50', 100, 2, 15, 163709) My meaning will perhaps become clearer if I describe here some of my experiences.
('50', 100, 2, 16, 163791) In Phoenix we had our daily prayers in the same way as in Sabarmati, and Mussalmans as well as Christians attended them along with Hindus.
('50', 100, 2, 17, 163930) The late Sheth Rustomji and his children too attended the prayer meetings.
('50', 100, 2, 18, 164005) Rustomji Sheth very much liked the Gujarati bhajan.
('50', 100, 2, 19, 164057) “Dear, dear to me is the name of Rama.” If my memory serves me right, Maganlal or Kashi was once leading us in singing this hymn, when Rustomji Sheth exclaimed joyously “Say the name of Hormazd instead of the name of Rama”.
('50', 100, 2, 20, 164281) His suggestion was readily taken up, and after that whenever the Sheth was present, and sometimes even when he was not, we put in the name of Hormazd in place of Rama.
('50', 100, 2, 21, 164449) The late Husain, son of Daud Sheth, often stayed at the Phoenix Ashram, and enthusiastically joined our prayers.
('50', 100, 2, 22, 164562) To the accompaniment of an organ, he used to sing in a very sweet voice the song “Hai bahare bagh”, “The garden of this world has only a momentary bloom”.
('50', 100, 2, 23, 164717) He taught us all this song, which we also sang at prayers.
('50', 100, 2, 24, 164776) Its inclusion in our Bhajanavali is a tribute to truth loving Husain’s memory.
('50', 100, 2, 25, 164855) I have never met a young man who practised Truth more devotedly than Husain.
('50', 100, 2, 26, 164932) Joseph Royeppen often came to Phoenix.
('50', 100, 2, 27, 164971) He was a Christian, and his favourite hymn was “Vaishnava
('50', 101, 0, 1, 165029) 102 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('50', 101, 1, 2, 165071) He loved music and once sang this hymn saying “Christian” in place of “vaishnava”.
('50', 101, 1, 3, 165154) The others accepted his reading with alacrity, and I observed that this filled Joseph’s heart with joy.
('50', 101, 1, 4, 165258) When I was turning over the pages of the sacred books of different faiths for my own satisfaction, I became sufficiently familiar for my purpose with Christianity, Islam, Zoroastrianism, Judaismand Hinduism.
('50', 101, 1, 5, 165466) In reading these texts, I can say that I felt the same regard for all these faiths although, perhaps, I was not then conscious of it.
('50', 101, 1, 6, 165600) Reviving my memory of those days, I do not find I ever had the slightest desire to criticize any of those religions merely because they were not my own, but read each sacred book in a spirit of reverence and found the same fundamental morality in each.
('50', 101, 1, 7, 165853) Some things I did not understand then, as I did not in Hindu scriptures.
('50', 101, 1, 8, 165926) I do not understand those things even now, but experience has taught me that it is a mistake hastily to imagine that anything that we cannot understand is necessarily wrong.
('50', 101, 1, 9, 166100) Some things which I did not understand first have since become as clear as daylight.
('50', 101, 1, 10, 166185) Equimin dedness helps us to solve many difficulties and even when we criticize anything, we express ourselves with a humility and courtesy which leave no sting behind them.
('50', 101, 1, 11, 166358) One difficulty still remains.
('50', 101, 1, 12, 166388) As I stated last time, the acceptance of the doctrine of Equality of Religions does not abolish the distinction between religion and irreligion.
('50', 101, 1, 13, 166533) We do not propose to cultivate tolerance for irreligion.
('50', 101, 1, 14, 166590) That being so, some people might object that there would be no room left for equimindedness, if everyone took his own decision as to what was religion and what was irreligion.
('50', 101, 1, 15, 166766) Such a question may be raised and one may even make a mistake in deciding what is religion and what is irreligion.
('50', 101, 1, 16, 166881) If, however, we follow the law of love, we shall not bear any hatred towards the irreligious brother.
('50', 101, 1, 17, 166983) On the contrary, though we see that he follows irreligion, we shall love him and, therefore, either we shall bring him to see the error of his ways or he will convince us of our error, or each will tolerate the other’s difference of opinion.
('50', 101, 1, 18, 167225) If the other party does not observe the law of love, he may be violent to us.
('50', 101, 1, 19, 167303) If, however, we cherish real love for him, it will overcome his bitterness in the end.
('50', 101, 1, 20, 167390) All obstacles in our path will vanish, if only we observe the golden rule that we must not be impatient with those whom we may consider to be in error, but must be prepared, if need be, to suffer in our own person.
('50', 102, 0, 1, 167605) VOL.50: 23 AUGUST, 1930 5 JANUARY, 1931 103
('50', 102, 1, 2, 167649) As I have stated earlier in this letter, I think I will omit the subject of swadeshi.
('50', 102, 1, 3, 167735) I have yet to think on what subject I shall write next.

('50', 103, 2, 3, 169036) YERAVDA MANDIR, October 2, 1930
('50', 103, 3, 4, 169068) PREMA, If you wish, you may certainly keep the wooden sandals.
('50', 103, 3, 5, 169131) But what will you do with those bits of wood?
('50', 103, 3, 6, 169177) Keep them if you think that they will add an inch or two to your stature.
('50', 103, 3, 7, 169251) I would condemn your action as smacking of idolatry.
('50', 103, 3, 8, 169304) I used to keep with me a photograph of my father.
('50', 103, 3, 9, 169354) I had hung his photographs in the drawing room and the bedroom when I was in South Africa.
('50', 103, 3, 10, 169445) When I used to wear a chain, it had a locket which contained small photographs of my father and elder brother.
('50', 103, 3, 11, 169556) I have now put them away.
('50', 103, 3, 12, 169582) That does not mean that I feel less reverence for them now.
('50', 103, 3, 13, 169642) In fact they are more deeply engraved in my heart today.
('50', 103, 3, 14, 169699) I think of their virtues and try to cultivate them.
('50', 103, 3, 15, 169751) I can worship countless gods in this manner.
('50', 103, 3, 16, 169796) If I tried to keep with me photographs of them all, I would have no room to put them in.
('50', 103, 3, 17, 169885) And if I tried to keep their wooden sandals, I should have to acquire a piece of land for the purpose.
('50', 103, 3, 18, 169988) As a man of experience, I advise you, therefore, to follow me when I am walking on the right path.
('50', 103, 3, 19, 170087) That will be a thousand times better than keeping my wooden sandals, and if anybody follows your example, I would welcome that.
('50', 103, 3, 20, 170215) On the contrary, if anybody saw the sandals with you and followed your example blindly, would he not fall into a pit?
('50', 103, 3, 21, 170333) Think on this and then do what you wish.

('50', 103, 3, 26, 170653) To give up our cravings is to become conscious of our duty.

('50', 105, 2, 3, 173013) YERAVDA MANDIR, October 2, 1930
('50', 105, 3, 4, 173045) GANGABEHN (SENIOR), I have your letter.
('50', 105, 3, 5, 173085) If you think you are not worthy of being a daughter, how much more fit should I become to be a worthy mother and father to you?
('50', 105, 3, 6, 173213) If I who claim to be both, am slack in my effort to be so, I shall have no place anywhere in the three worlds.
('50', 105, 3, 7, 173324) Let us, therefore, not argue who is worthy and who is not.
('50', 105, 3, 8, 173383) If a son or daughter is unworthy, the parents bear no small responsibility for that.
('50', 105, 3, 9, 173468) I understand the reason for your depression.
('50', 105, 3, 10, 173513) Instead of thinking that you have to do this, that or the other thing, you should think that God does all that and uses you as His instrument.
('50', 105, 3, 11, 173656) If you think thus, you will feel no burden at all.
('50', 105, 3, 12, 173707) It is God who carries the burden, and His shoulders are so broad that however heavy the burden we place on them He does not feel it even as much as we would a speck of dust on our hand.
('50', 105, 3, 13, 173893) We should, therefore, forget ‘I’ and ‘Mine’.
('50', 105, 3, 14, 173938) “It is I who do this— that is our ignorance, like that of the dog who thinks he draws the cart”: this line by Narasinh Mehta expresses his own experience.
('50', 105, 3, 15, 174093) ‘Shakat’ in this line means a cart.
('50', 105, 3, 16, 174129) If we believe that the dog who walks under a moving cart draws it, then we may believe that the burden of our tasks is on us; but anyone who works for the love of God will never find his task a heavier burden than he can carry.
('50', 105, 3, 17, 174357) He does not have to take upon himself anything.
('50', 105, 3, 18, 174405) Tasks come to him unsought.
('50', 105, 3, 19, 174433) He goes on working cheerfully, with God’s name upon his lips.
('50', 105, 3, 20, 174495) You sing with sincere emotion: “Make me your servant.” Think over the meaning of that bhajan.
('50', 105, 3, 21, 174589) Also think over the meaning of the two verses which we have added to the prayers for women.
('50', 105, 3, 22, 174681) It is the Lord’s assurance to those who surrender themselves to Him that He will carry the burden of their happiness and welfare.
('50', 105, 3, 23, 174811) Why, then, should we worry?
('50', 105, 3, 24, 174839) This is looking at the matter philosophically.
('50', 105, 3, 25, 174886) But even if you and I feel agitated, what escape is there for us?
('50', 105, 3, 26, 174952) Our relationship with the Ashram is like the Hindu marriage bond.
('50', 105, 3, 27, 175018) The tie can never be loosened.
('50', 105, 3, 28, 175049) Instead of thinking whetherothers are half hearted or firm in their attitude, you should ask
('50', 106, 0, 1, 175142) VOL.50: 23 AUGUST, 1930 5 JANUARY, 1931 107
('50', 106, 1, 2, 175186) yourself whether you are half hearted or firm, and that is all that is necessary.
('50', 106, 1, 3, 175268) Certainly seek what comfort Nath can give you.
('50', 106, 1, 4, 175315) Talk with Narandas and pour out your heart every week to me.
('50', 106, 1, 5, 175376) If you can free yourself for a few days and pay a visit to Kakasaheb, that, too, will give you some comfort.
('50', 106, 1, 6, 175485) Do not work so hard that you get exhausted.
('50', 106, 1, 7, 175529) One should always preserve a sense of proportion in undertaking work in the spirit of service.
('50', 106, 1, 8, 175624) We can do that only if we have cultivated the attitude of non attachment.
('50', 106, 1, 9, 175698) Non attachment means freedom from the sense of ‘I’ and ‘Mine’.
('50', 106, 1, 10, 175761) The saying that while sleeping one should stretch out one’s limbs according to the length of the covering has great wisdom behind it.

('50', 109, 6, 11, 179639) 160. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('50', 109, 7, 12, 179663) YERAVDA MANDIR, October 5, 1930
('50', 109, 8, 13, 179695) MIRA, I am writing this after taking silence.
('50', 109, 8, 14, 179741) Have just seen your portrait in a group published in the Times Illustrated Weekly.
('50', 109, 8, 15, 179824) You are spinning on the takli and looking fit.
('50', 109, 8, 16, 179871) Then I saw in the columns of The Bombay Chronicle that you were in the women’s procession and spoke at their meeting.
('50', 109, 8, 17, 179989) So you are again near my lodgings and probably this will be in your hands at the Ashram.
('50', 109, 8, 18, 180078) Yes, S. Aiengar’s daughter is a very good woman but she was hysterical even when we were travelling from Mysore.
('50', 109, 8, 19, 180191) When you write to her please give my love to her and tell her I often think of her.
('50', 109, 8, 20, 180275) It is a sad thing—her father’s case.
('50', 109, 8, 21, 180312) It is the same thing with him as with the daughter.
('50', 109, 8, 22, 180364) He can be hardly considered responsible for many of his strange acts.
('50', 109, 8, 23, 180434) Did you see him at all?
('50', 109, 8, 24, 180458) Where did you stay whilst in Madras?
('50', 109, 8, 25, 180495) Last week, Kaka having been given my wheel, I thought I would finish my quota on yours.
('50', 109, 8, 26, 180583) I tried hard but I could not make it work.
('50', 109, 8, 27, 180626) The spindle won’t turn.
('50', 109, 8, 28, 180650) Whether the resin was ineffective or what the cause was, I could not divine.
('50', 109, 8, 29, 180727) But there it was refusing to turn.
('50', 109, 8, 30, 180762) Then I thought of the Gandiv of Surat.
('50', 109, 8, 31, 180801) I found it to be an extraordinarily effective thing.
('50', 109, 8, 32, 180854) For the last two days I have been finishing the whole
('50', 110, 0, 1, 180908) VOL.50: 23 AUGUST, 1930 5 JANUARY, 1931 111
('50', 110, 1, 2, 180952) of my quota on it and that in very good time and without the slighest fatigue.
('50', 110, 1, 3, 181031) It has captivated me and I want you to try it.
('50', 110, 1, 4, 181078) It is essentially a poor man’s wheel.
('50', 110, 1, 5, 181116) The inventor is no mechanic.
('50', 110, 1, 6, 181145) How it has come to him, I do not know.
('50', 110, 1, 7, 181184) But every part of it, in my opinion, shows solicitude for the starving.
('50', 110, 1, 8, 181256) It costs Rs. 1 1/2 but it can be made for only 8 annas, I am sure.
('50', 110, 1, 9, 181323) It is the lightest wheel going in India.
('50', 110, 1, 10, 181364) It requires the least attention.
('50', 110, 1, 11, 181397) It occupies the smallest space of all the wheels I know.
('50', 110, 1, 12, 181454) A little child can work at it.
('50', 110, 1, 13, 181485) Thousands of these wheels can be manufactured in a day if the discs and spindles are kept in stock.
('50', 110, 1, 14, 181585) Its mechanism is simplicity personified.
('50', 110, 1, 15, 181626) You naturally draw a fine thread.
('50', 110, 1, 16, 181660) The very first I drew was over 30 counts.
('50', 110, 1, 17, 181702) And I fancy that it can compete with any in giving speed.
('50', 110, 1, 18, 181760) It admits of certain improvements, which can be made without adding a pice to the cost.
('50', 110, 1, 19, 181848) I have made two and this reduces the cost.
('50', 110, 1, 20, 181891) The original has noisy wooden holders.

('50', 121, 8, 15, 201049) I approve of your idea of reading the Ramayana among the village people and cultivating contacts with them by that means.

('50', 123, 11, 18, 204372) Y. M., October 11, 1930
('50', 123, 13, 19, 204396) I have your letter.
('50', 123, 13, 20, 204416) You are greedy.
('50', 123, 13, 21, 204432) It is of course good to be greedy when you are young.
('50', 123, 13, 22, 204486) But while being greedy one should also exercise restraint.
('50', 123, 13, 23, 204545) Hence, of all the things you may wish to learn you should first learn what will be more useful for service.
('50', 123, 13, 24, 204653) Another restraint is that whatever you learn you must do thoroughly and not leave half way.
('50', 123, 13, 25, 204745) Do learn sewing.
('50', 123, 13, 26, 204762) But do not be hasty.
('50', 123, 13, 27, 204783) One reason why
('50', 124, 0, 1, 204798) VOL.50: 23 AUGUST, 1930 5 JANUARY, 1931 125
('50', 124, 1, 2, 204842) you do not enjoy weaving is that you do not yet know it well.
('50', 124, 1, 3, 204904) In the beginning all efforts at learning seem uninteresting.
('50', 124, 1, 4, 204965) Many people do not like arithmetic because they find it difficult to learn.
('50', 124, 1, 5, 205041) But those who know it can enjoy it as much as they would a novel.
('50', 124, 1, 6, 205107) Another reason is that you do not still have enough love for the poor.
('50', 124, 1, 7, 205178) How can a person who realizes that every yard of khadi that he produces will help to cover the back of a poor man fail to take pleasure in producing it?
('50', 124, 1, 8, 205331) A mother does with joy for her child and God for his bhakta what other people would find a boring task.
('50', 124, 1, 9, 205435) The truth is that we do not as yet feel real love of service.
('50', 124, 1, 10, 205497) A servant should find equal pleasure in all forms of service.
('50', 124, 1, 11, 205559) All service given sincerely is of equal worth.
('50', 124, 1, 12, 205606) Ponder over the verse “He who offers me with devotion a leaf, a flower, or fruit or water.

('50', 125, 6, 8, 206901) BHAGWANJI, The Ashram is for the men of ordinary category.
('50', 125, 6, 9, 206960) It cannot be said that the Ashram is curt towards Girirajji if he has reached the height you regard him to have reached, but that his great soul can no more be accommodated there.
('50', 125, 6, 10, 207140) The decision taken by Narandas is spiritual.

('50', 125, 6, 12, 207285) Personally I think Giriraj has fallen into delusion.
('50', 125, 6, 13, 207338) I would not engage myself or involve another in the regimen undertaken by us if it is not going to help us realize the atman.
('50', 125, 6, 14, 207464) It is possible that God might live in the house of a scavenger and He may not be found in that of a Vedantin.

('50', 125, 6, 16, 207626) Giriraj is a noble person, he is humble too; he will therefore come round after his ramblings.
