('50', 126, 2, 3, 208041) YERAVDA MANDIR, October 12, 1930
('50', 126, 3, 4, 208074) KASHINATH, I have your letter.
('50', 126, 3, 5, 208105) There is not the slightest reason to be grieved by the death of friends.
('50', 126, 3, 6, 208178) None ever dies before his time.
('50', 126, 3, 7, 208210) The notion of untimely death is a delusion.
('50', 126, 3, 8, 208254) Even the death of a day old baby is not an untimely one.
('50', 126, 3, 9, 208311) It only means that the actions to be performed through that body had been performed.
('50', 126, 3, 10, 208396) We feel pained by death only because of our ignorance and selfishness.
('50', 126, 3, 11, 208467) We feel agitated over thedeath of friends or others because of our ignorance of the soul’s attributes and because we do not wish ourselves to die.
('50', 126, 3, 12, 208614) Yes, we owe a duty to the widows.

('50', 126, 3, 19, 209076) Mahavir Prasad’s zeal is beyond praise.
('50', 126, 3, 20, 209116) He has already started working for the third edition of the Gita.
('50', 126, 3, 21, 209182) You ought to get over your depression now.
('50', 126, 3, 22, 209225) If any depressing thoughts or impure desires arise in your mind, note them every time and drive them out.
('50', 126, 3, 23, 209331) Do not let your mind dwell on them; do not even debate within your mind how they occurred, but keep the mind engaged in good thoughts.
('50', 126, 3, 24, 209466) The golden means of doing which is that the mind, too, should be kept fully occupied in some external activity, so that it may have no time at all to wander.

('50', 130, 0, 1, 213286) VOL.50: 23 AUGUST, 1930 5 JANUARY, 1931 131
('50', 130, 1, 2, 213330) 191. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('50', 130, 2, 3, 213354) [October 13, 1930] 1
('50', 130, 4, 4, 213375) I hope you have got the straying letters.
('50', 130, 4, 5, 213417) I am sure they have not been intercepted, but have been delayed in transit from place to place.
('50', 130, 5, 6, 213513) It is evident, my ‘scolding’ as you call it, was well deserved, for you have returned in a dilapidated condition.
('50', 130, 5, 7, 213627) On the top of that, you had a bad accident.
('50', 130, 5, 8, 213671) Now you would be as good as your word and take full rest.
('50', 130, 5, 9, 213729) I was much relieved to understand that you had been visiting the Sardar.
('50', 130, 5, 10, 213802) That showed that you were well enough to travel.
('50', 130, 5, 11, 213851) I am still at the Gandiv wheel, and my rapture continues, if anything it has increased.
('50', 130, 5, 12, 213939) I am spinning scientifically now, i.e., with a yard measure underneath the track of the yarn as it is drawn.
('50', 130, 5, 13, 214048) I can draw 8 threads in one minute and I pull at least two feet to each draw.
('50', 130, 5, 14, 214126) This means 240 rounds or 300 yards per hour.
('50', 130, 5, 15, 214171) But of course, I do nothingof the sort in an hour but that is not because of any defect in the Gandiv.
('50', 130, 5, 16, 214274) The less output is due to breakages and consequent waste of time.

('50', 134, 0, 1, 220434) VOL.50: 23 AUGUST, 1930 5 JANUARY, 1931 135
('50', 134, 1, 2, 220478) Tuesday morning, October 14, 1930
('50', 134, 2, 3, 220512) In this series, I have dealt cursorily with the importance of vows, but it is perhaps necessary to consider at some length their bearing on a godly life.
('50', 134, 2, 4, 220666) Now that I have discussed all our vows except that of swadeshi, let us consider the necessity of vows.
('50', 134, 2, 5, 220769) There is a powerful school of thinkers who concede the propriety of observing certain rules but do not acknowledge the necessity of vows.
('50', 134, 2, 6, 220907) They go even so far as to suggest that vows are a sign of weakness and may even be harmful.
('50', 134, 2, 7, 220999) Again they say that, if a rule is subsequently discovered to be inconvenient or sinful, to adhere to it after such discovery would be positively wrong.
('50', 134, 2, 8, 221151) They say: “It is a good thing to abstain from liquor, but what harm is there in taking it occasionally, say on medical grounds?
('50', 134, 2, 9, 221279) A pledge of total abstinence would be a needless handicap; and as with liquor, so with other things.
('50', 134, 2, 10, 221380) Why may we not even speak an untruth for a good end?” This argument does not convince me.
('50', 134, 2, 11, 221470) A vow means unflinching determination, and helps us against temptations.
('50', 134, 2, 12, 221543) Determination is worth nothing if it bends before discomfort.
('50', 134, 2, 13, 221605) The universal experience of humanity supports the view that progress isimpossible without inflexible determination.
('50', 134, 2, 14, 221721) There cannot be a vow to commit a sin.
('50', 134, 2, 15, 221760) Such a vow represents a wicked nature.
('50', 134, 2, 16, 221799) In the case of a vow first thought to be meritorious but later found to be sinful, there arises a clear necessity to give it up.
('50', 134, 2, 17, 221928) But no one takes, or ought to take, vows about dubious matters.
('50', 134, 2, 18, 221992) Vows can be taken only on points of universally recognized principles, which, however, we do not habitually act upon.
('50', 134, 2, 19, 222110) The possibility of sin in such a case is more or less imaginary.
('50', 134, 2, 20, 222175) A devotee of Truth cannot stop to consider if someone will not be injured by his telling the truth, for he believes that truth can never do harm.
('50', 134, 2, 21, 222321) So also about total abstinence.
('50', 134, 2, 22, 222353) The abstainer will either make an exception as regards medicine, or will be prepared to risk his life in fulfilment of his full vow.
('50', 134, 2, 23, 222486) What does it matter if we happen to lose our lives through a pledge of total abstinence?
('50', 134, 2, 24, 222575) There can be no guarantee that our lives will be prolonged by liquor, and even if life is thus prolonged for a moment, it may be ended the very next through some other agency.
('50', 134, 2, 25, 222751) On the other hand, the example of a man who gives up his life rather than his pledge is likely to wean drunkards from liquor and thus become a great power for good in the world.
('50', 134, 2, 26, 222929) Only they can hope some time to
('50', 135, 0, 1, 222961) 136 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('50', 135, 1, 2, 223003) see God who have nobly determined to bear witness to the faith that is in them even at the cost of life itself.
('50', 135, 1, 3, 223115) Taking vows is not a sign of weakness but of strength.
('50', 135, 1, 4, 223170) To do at any cost what one ought to do constitutes a vow.
('50', 135, 1, 5, 223228) It becomes a bulwark of strength.
('50', 135, 1, 6, 223262) It makes no difference whether such a resolve is called a vow or known by some other name.
('50', 135, 1, 7, 223353) A man, who says that he will do something “as far as possible” betrays either his pride or his weakness, though he himself may attribute it to his humility.
('50', 135, 1, 8, 223510) There is, in fact, not a trace of humility in such an attitude of mind.
('50', 135, 1, 9, 223582) I have noticed in my own case, as well as in that of others, that the limitation “as far as possible” provides a fatal loophole.
('50', 135, 1, 10, 223711) To do something “as far as possible” is to succumb to the very first temptation.
('50', 135, 1, 11, 223792) There is no sense in saying that we will observe truth “as far as possible”.
('50', 135, 1, 12, 223869) Even as no businessman will look at a note in which a man promises to pay a certain amount on a certain date “as far as possible”, so will God refuse to accept a promissory note drawn by a man who will observe truth “as far as possible”.
('50', 135, 1, 13, 224107) God is the very image of the vow.
('50', 135, 1, 14, 224141) God would cease to be God if He swerved from His own laws even by a hair’s breadth.
('50', 135, 1, 15, 224225) The sun is a great keeper of observances; hence the possibility of measuring timeand publishing almanacs.
('50', 135, 1, 16, 224331) He has created in us the faith that he always rises and will for ever continue to rise, and thereby given us a sense of security.
('50', 135, 1, 17, 224461) All business depends upon men fulfilling their promises.
('50', 135, 1, 18, 224518) There could be no commerce if merchants did not regard themselves as bound by their word to one another.
('50', 135, 1, 19, 224623) We thus see that keeping a vow is a universal practice.
('50', 135, 1, 20, 224679) Are such promises less necessary in character building or self realization?
('50', 135, 1, 21, 224755) We should, therefore, never doubt the necessity of vows for the purpose of self purification and self realization.
('50', 135, 2, 22, 224870) Blessings from BAPU [PS.] About the Gandiv spinning wheel and about my diet you will get some news in my letter to Mirabehn.
('50', 135, 2, 23, 224995) There are 63 letters today.

('50', 138, 8, 19, 228668) There are two kinds of eggs, one to which exception may be taken and the other unexceptionable.
('50', 138, 8, 20, 228764) The former are those which ultimately produce chicken, and the unexceptionable are those which produce no life.
('50', 138, 8, 21, 228876) Hens lay such eggs without their having been inseminated by cocks.
('50', 138, 8, 22, 228943) This is a well known fact.
('50', 138, 8, 23, 228970) Parnerkar will probably know about it.
('50', 138, 8, 24, 229009) Such eggs are available in the market.
('50', 138, 8, 25, 229048) Mostly Europeans look after the production of such eggs.
('50', 138, 8, 26, 229105) There is a farm for this purpose near Miraj.
('50', 138, 8, 27, 229150) You will find some correspondence on this subject in my file.
('50', 138, 8, 28, 229212) You need not, however, search for it.
('50', 138, 8, 29, 229250) Many Parsis in Ahmedabad will be able to give you information about where such eggs are available.
('50', 138, 8, 30, 229349) Personally I believe that eggs of this kind are less
('50', 138, 9, 31, 229402) 1 As in the printed source
('50', 139, 0, 1, 229429) 140 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('50', 139, 1, 2, 229471) objectionable than milk.
('50', 139, 1, 3, 229496) In eating them, we do not deprive any creature of its food, as we do by taking milk.
('50', 139, 1, 4, 229581) If Amidas agrees, obtain such eggs immediately.
('50', 139, 1, 5, 229629) They are to be used in this manner.
('50', 139, 1, 6, 229665) Break an unfertilised egg, mix its contents with eight ounces of water and keep the mixture in a bottle.
('50', 139, 1, 7, 229770) Give him an ounce of this mixture every hour.
('50', 139, 1, 8, 229816) He will soon gain strength.
('50', 139, 1, 9, 229844) The mixture will completely serve the purpose of milk.
('50', 139, 1, 10, 229899) I can say that Manu’s life was saved by this mixture.
('50', 139, 1, 11, 229953) Such eggs are a hundred times better than cod liver oil.

('50', 139, 1, 13, 230098) I have not publicly advocated the use of such eggs because, when self indulgence is on the increase and all kinds of medicines are being consumed without hesitation, I did not think it proper to add one more to the list.

('50', 139, 4, 18, 230533) 201. LETTER TO SUSHILA GANDHI
('50', 139, 5, 19, 230563) [Before October 17, 1930] 1

('50', 150, 1, 2, 243566) 219. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('50', 150, 2, 3, 243590) YERAVDA MANDIR, October 19, 1930
('50', 150, 3, 4, 243623) MIRA, I have your letter from Bombay.
('50', 150, 3, 5, 243661) I was glad to learn that you were feeling better.
('50', 150, 3, 6, 243711) You must not let the mind get into the state described by you.
('50', 150, 3, 7, 243774) If you work with detachment, you will refuse to be rushed and you will refuse to let anything get on your nerves.
('50', 150, 3, 8, 243888) Having put one’s whole heart into a thing entrusted or undertaken, one can leave the result to God.
('50', 150, 3, 9, 243988) Then there can be no rush and no worry.
('50', 150, 3, 10, 244028) You know the story of King Janak.
('50', 150, 3, 11, 244062) He was Duty personified.
('50', 150, 3, 12, 244087) His capital was in flames.
('50', 150, 3, 13, 244114) He knew it.
('50', 150, 3, 14, 244126) But some busybody reported it to him.
('50', 150, 3, 15, 244164) His answer was, “What care I whether my capital is reduced to ashes or remains intact!” He had done all he could to save it.
('50', 150, 3, 16, 244289) His going to the scene of operations and fussing would have distracted the attention of the fire brigade and others and made matters worse.
('50', 150, 3, 17, 244429) He was but an agent of providence.
('50', 150, 3, 18, 244464) As such he had done his part and was therefore ‘quits’ and at ease.
('50', 150, 3, 19, 244532) So may, must, we be, if we have done our best, whether our work flourishes or perishes.
('50', 150, 3, 20, 244620) The Gandiv still gives me joy and satisfaction.
('50', 150, 3, 21, 244668) Nothing has yet broken down.
('50', 150, 3, 22, 244697) Whereas I took five hours before, I now finish well within 3 hours.
('50', 150, 3, 23, 244765) The afternoon is now free for other work except for the takli.
('50', 150, 3, 24, 244828) So on your travels you may take the Gandiv if it gives you as much satisfaction as it gives to me.
('50', 150, 3, 25, 244927) The cost of the pattern that I have is one rupee including the spindle and a box scooped in the platform and an incredibly simple device for keeping the spindle on one side of the platform.
('50', 150, 3, 26, 245117) For price and simplicity this wheel has no match.
('50', 150, 3, 27, 245167) I have discarded the bamboo holders and the wretched glass cylinders.
('50', 150, 3, 28, 245237) I think I told you this.
('50', 150, 3, 29, 245262) And it works without any foreign sound at all.

('50', 157, 3, 4, 252975) NARANDAS, I have your letter.
('50', 157, 3, 5, 253005) The occasional delay in your getting my letters can’t be helped.
('50', 157, 3, 6, 253070) “Make the best of today, for who knows what tomorrow will bring?” This is true of our present circumstances too.
('50', 157, 3, 7, 253183) If the men in charge of the factory at Bardoli have not been arrested, what about the goods in factory?
('50', 157, 3, 8, 253287) I read in newspapers that they, too, were confiscated.
('50', 157, 3, 9, 253342) It was a matter of surprise that the Ashram had remained free from malaria.
('50', 157, 3, 10, 253418) At last it could remain so no longer.
('50', 157, 3, 11, 253456) I think it can be kept free from it.
('50', 157, 3, 12, 253493) In the malarial season, one should take care and see that one’s stomach is light.
('50', 157, 3, 13, 253575) Starchy and other indigestible foods, like pulses, should be avoided.
('50', 157, 3, 14, 253645) If those who have escaped malaria so far take care, they will be able to preserve their health.
('50', 157, 3, 15, 253741) The water in the well should be disinfected with potassium permanganate or chlorine.
('50', 157, 3, 16, 253826) I think these can also be added in the water fetched from the river.
('50', 157, 3, 17, 253895) If a few drops of the solution are poured into the river water where it is stored, it will acquire a light rose colour.
('50', 157, 3, 18, 254015) After a while, the colour will settle at the bottom.
('50', 157, 3, 19, 254068) You should consult a doctor for more information about this.
('50', 157, 3, 20, 254129) I will write a separate letter about Amidas, 1

('50', 159, 1, 2, 257228) I wrote to you last Friday about Amidas.
('50', 159, 1, 3, 257269) You must have received the letter.

('50', 159, 2, 8, 257468) Read my letter about Kanta.
('50', 159, 2, 9, 257496) It seems she wants to go out for a few days at least.
('50', 159, 2, 10, 257550) Think about the matter.
('50', 159, 2, 11, 257574) From here, what I feel is that she may go for a few days wherever she likes.
('50', 159, 2, 12, 257651) She is both truthful and brave.

('50', 159, 2, 18, 257862) Tuesday morning, Diwali,
('50', 159, 3, 19, 257887) October 21, 1930 My blessings to all the friends there.
('50', 159, 3, 20, 257943) My Vandemataram and due regards to everyone.
('50', 159, 3, 21, 257988) May we be filled with greater spirit of service during the next year, and become fitter instruments and more awake to our duty in that regard.
('50', 159, 3, 22, 258131) We make frequent use of the word ‘yajna’.
('50', 159, 3, 23, 258173) We have raised spinning to the rank of a daily mahayajna.
('50', 159, 3, 24, 258231) It is therefore necessary to think out the various implications of the term ‘yajna’.
('50', 159, 3, 25, 258316) ‘Yajna’ means an act directed to the welfare of others, done without desiring any return for it, whether of a temporal or spiritual nature.
('50', 159, 3, 26, 258456) ‘Act’ here must be taken in its widest sense, and includes thought and word, as well as deed.
('50', 159, 3, 27, 258550) ‘Others’ embraces not only humanity, but all life.
('50', 159, 3, 28, 258601) Therefore, and also from the standpoint of ahimsa, it is not a yajna to sacrifice lower animals even with a view to serving humanity.
('50', 159, 3, 29, 258735) It does not matter that animal sacrifice is supposed to find a place in the Vedas.
('50', 159, 3, 30, 258818) It is enough for us that such sacrifice cannot stand the fundamental tests of Truth and Non violence.
('50', 159, 3, 31, 258920) I readily admit my incompetence in Vedic scholarship.
('50', 159, 3, 32, 258974) But the incompetence, so far as this subject is concerned, does not worry me because, even if the practice of animal sacrifice be proved to have been a feature of Vedic society, it can form no precedent for a votary of ahimsa.
('50', 159, 3, 33, 259201) From this definition of yajna it follows that a primary sacrifice must be an act which conduces the most to the welfare of the greatest number in the widest area, and which can be performed by the largest number of men and women with the least trouble.
('50', 159, 3, 34, 259454) It will not, therefore, be a yajna, much less a mahayajna, to wish or to do ill to
('50', 160, 0, 1, 259537) VOL.50 : 23 AUGUST, 1930 5 JANUARY, 1931 161
('50', 160, 1, 2, 259582) anyone else even in order to serve a so called higher interest.
('50', 160, 1, 3, 259646) And the Gita teaches, and experience testifies, that all action that cannot come under the category of yajna promotes bondage.
('50', 160, 1, 4, 259773) The world cannot subsist for a single moment without yajna in this sense and, therefore, the Gita, after having dealt with true wisdom in the second chapter, takes up in the third the means of attaining it and declares in so many words that yajna came with Creation itself.
('50', 160, 1, 5, 260047) This body, therefore, has been given us only inorder that we may serve all Creation with it.
('50', 160, 1, 6, 260140) And therefore, says the Gita, he who eats without offering yajna eats stolen food.
('50', 160, 1, 7, 260223) Every single act of one who would lead a life of purity should be in the nature of yajna.
('50', 160, 1, 8, 260313) Yajna having come to us with our birth, we are debtors all our lives and thus for ever bound to serve the universe.
('50', 160, 1, 9, 260429) And even as a bondslave receives food, clothing and so on from the master whom he serves, so should we gratefully accept such gifts as may be assigned to us by the Lord of the universe.
('50', 160, 1, 10, 260615) What we receive must be called a gift; for as debtors we are entitled to no consideration for the discharge of our obligations.
('50', 160, 1, 11, 260743) Therefore we may not blame the Master if we fail to get it.
('50', 160, 1, 12, 260803) Our body is His to be cherished or cast away according to His will.
('50', 160, 1, 13, 260871) This is not a matter for complaint or even pity; on the contrary, it is a natural and even a pleasant and desirable state, if only we realize our proper place in God’s scheme.
('50', 160, 1, 14, 261047) We do indeed need strong faith, if we would experience this supreme bliss.
('50', 160, 1, 15, 261122) “Do not worry in the least about yourself, leave all worry to God,”—this appears to be the commandment in all religions.
('50', 160, 1, 16, 261243) This need not frighten anyone.
('50', 160, 1, 17, 261274) He who devotes himself to service with a clear conscience will day by day grasp the necessity for it in greater measure and will continually grow richer in faith.
('50', 160, 1, 18, 261437) The path of service can hardly be trodden by one who is not prepared to renounce self interest and to recognize the conditions of his birth.
('50', 160, 1, 19, 261578) Any service rendered by such a person will be tainted by selfishness.
('50', 160, 1, 20, 261648) But, then, men of such utter selfishness are rare in this world.
('50', 160, 1, 21, 261713) Consciously or unconsciously, every one of us does render some service or other.
('50', 160, 1, 22, 261794) If we cultivate the habit of doing this service deliberately, our desire for service will steadily grow stronger and will make not only for our own happiness but also for that of the world at large.
('50', 160, 2, 23, 261993) Blessings from BAPU [PS.] There are 58 letters today.

('50', 180, 2, 9, 288552) Tuesday morning, October 28, 1930
('50', 180, 3, 10, 288586) I wrote about yajna last week, but feel like writing more about it.
('50', 180, 3, 11, 288654) It will perhaps be worthwhile further to consider a principle which has been created along with mankind.
('50', 180, 3, 12, 288759) Yajna is duty to be performed, or service to be rendered, all the twenty four hours of the day, and hence a maxim like “The powers of the good are always exercised for a benevolent purpose” is inappropriate, if benevolence has any taste of favour about it.
('50', 180, 3, 13, 289016) To serve without desire is to favour not others, but ourselves even as in discharging a debt we serve only ourselves, lighten our burden and fulfil our duty.
('50', 180, 3, 14, 289174) Again, not only the good, but all of us are bound to place our resources at the disposal of humanity.
('50', 180, 3, 15, 289276) And if such is the law, as evidently it is, indulgence ceases to hold a place in life and gives way to renunciation.
('50', 180, 3, 16, 289393) For human beings renunciation itself is enjoyment.
('50', 180, 3, 17, 289444) This is what differentiates man from the beast.
('50', 180, 3, 18, 289492) Some object that life thus understood becomes dull and devoid of art, and leaves no room for the householder.
('50', 180, 3, 19, 289602) But I think in saying this they misinterpret the word ‘renunciation’.
('50', 180, 3, 20, 289672) Renunciation here does not mean abandoning the world and retiring into the forest.
('50', 180, 3, 21, 289755) The spirit of renunciation, should rule all the activities of life.
('50', 180, 3, 22, 289823) A householder does not cease to be one if he regards life as a duty rather than as an indulgence.
('50', 180, 3, 23, 289921) A cobbler, a cultivator, a tradesman or a barber may be inspired in their work or activities either by the spirit of renunciation or merely by the desire for self indulgence.
('50', 180, 3, 24, 290096) A merchant who carries on his business in a spirit of sacrifice will have crores passing through his hands, but he will, if he follows the law, use his abilities for service.
('50', 180, 3, 25, 290271) He will, therefore, not cheat or speculate, will lead a simple life, will not injure a living soul and will lose millions rather than harm anybody.
('50', 180, 3, 26, 290419) Let no one run away with the idea that this type of merchant exists only in my imagination.
('50', 180, 3, 27, 290511) Fortunately for the world, he does exist in the West as well as in the East.
('50', 180, 3, 28, 290588) It is true such merchants may be counted on one’s fingers but the type ceases to be
('50', 181, 0, 1, 290672) 182 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('50', 181, 1, 2, 290714) imaginary as soon as even one living specimen can be found to answer to it.
('50', 181, 1, 3, 290790) All of us know of a philanthropic tailor in Wadhwan.
('50', 181, 1, 4, 290843) I know of one such barber.
('50', 181, 1, 5, 290870) Everyone of us knows of such a weaver.
('50', 181, 2, 6, 290909) And if we go deeply into the matter, we shall come across men in every walk of life who lead dedicated lives.
('50', 181, 2, 7, 291019) No doubt these sacrificers obtain their livelihood by their work.
('50', 181, 2, 8, 291085) But livelihood is not their objective, but only a by product of their vocation.

('50', 181, 2, 20, 291920) We shall delight in things which we have been taught to delight in as children.
('50', 181, 2, 21, 292000) And illustrations can be easily cited of different national tastes.
('50', 181, 2, 22, 292068) Again, many sacrificers imagine that they are free to receive from the people everything they need and many things they do not need, because they are rendering disinterested service.
('50', 181, 2, 23, 292251) Directly this idea sways a man, he ceases to be a servant and becomes a tyrant over the people.
('50', 181, 2, 24, 292347) One who would serve others will not waste a thought upon his own comforts, which he leaves to be attended to or neglected by his Master on high.
('50', 181, 2, 25, 292492) He will not, therefore, encumber himself with everything that comes his way; he will take only what he strictly needs and leave the rest.
('50', 181, 2, 26, 292630) He will be calm, free from anger and unruffled in mind even if he finds himself inconvenienced.
('50', 181, 2, 27, 292726) His service, like virtue, is its own reward, and he will rest content with it.
('50', 181, 2, 28, 292805) Again, one dare not be negligent in service or be behindhand with it.

('50', 182, 6, 15, 294063) My hope in making this request is that, if you do not keep a stock of such cotton, you will start doing so.

('50', 182, 6, 17, 294215) It is difficult to card with hand the cotton from the bales prepared in a ginning press, and the yarn spun from such cotton is not of good quality.
('50', 182, 6, 18, 294363) If you do not keep a stock of such cotton ginned by hand, you may obtain some from the Ashram or from Vithaldas Jerajani.
('50', 182, 6, 19, 294485) It may also be available in the Khadi Karyalaya.
('50', 182, 6, 20, 294534) I make this request so that you may take all this trouble.
('50', 182, 6, 21, 294593) Kakasaheb and I have been making the fullest use of your sewing machine.
('50', 182, 7, 22, 294666) Blessings from MOHANDAS

('50', 185, 5, 10, 298132) 270. LETTER TO J. C. KUMARAPPA
('50', 185, 6, 11, 298163) October 31, 1930
('50', 185, 7, 12, 298180) MY DEAR KUMARAPPA, I am glad you have expressed yourself freely on the question of ‘vows’.
('50', 185, 7, 13, 298271) You seem to me to misunderstand my meaning.
('50', 185, 7, 14, 298315) No fault of yours.
('50', 185, 7, 15, 298334) You have not the original before you.
('50', 185, 7, 16, 298372) I have not seen the translation.
('50', 185, 7, 17, 298405) The word ‘vow’ is also an unsuitable equivalent for the original ‘ozr’.
('50', 185, 7, 18, 298477) But the best thing for me is to explain what I mean and then leave you to find the exact word if you endorse my position.
('50', 185, 7, 19, 298599) If you contest it, you should continue the correspondence till we have thrashed the subject out.
('50', 185, 7, 20, 298696) You seem to think of vows publicly administered to audiences.
('50', 185, 7, 21, 298758) This may or may not be good.
('50', 185, 7, 22, 298787) The ‘vow’ I am thinking of is a promise made by one to oneself.
('50', 185, 7, 23, 298851) We have to deal with two dwellers within: Rama and Ravana, God and Satan, Ormuzd 2 and Ahriman 3 .
('50', 185, 7, 24, 298950) The one binds us to make us really free, the other only appears to free us so as to bind us tight within his grip.
('50', 185, 7, 25, 299065) A ‘vow’ is a promise made to Rama to do or not to do a certain thing which, if good, we want to do,
('50', 185, 8, 26, 299165) 1 The letter was written while Gandhiji was in custody and not able to speak his mind.
('50', 185, 8, 27, 299252) 2 The holy and the evil spirits according to Zoroastrian scriptures 3 ibid
('50', 186, 0, 1, 299327) VOL.50 : 23 AUGUST, 1930 5 JANUARY, 1931 187
('50', 186, 1, 2, 299372) but have not the strength unless we are tied down, and which, if bad, we would avoid, but have not the strength to avoid unless similarly tied down.
('50', 186, 1, 3, 299521) This I hold to be a condition indispensable [to] 1 growth.
('50', 186, 1, 4, 299580) I grant that we are higher than the sun, how much more necessary for us to be at least as true and faithful as the sun if not truer and more faithful?
('50', 186, 1, 5, 299731) If in matters of commerce, a man who vacillates is useless, why should he fare otherwise in matters spiritual which carry with them infinitely greater consequences?
('50', 186, 1, 6, 299896) If you hold that I must speak and do the right thing at any cost, you grant my whole position and so you also do if you grant that, at the peril of my life, I should be faithful to my wife or friend.
('50', 186, 1, 7, 300096) You can easily multiply such instances.
('50', 186, 1, 8, 300136) For me Jesus was pre eminently a man of unshakable resolution, i.e., vows.
('50', 186, 1, 9, 300211) His yea was yea for ever.
('50', 186, 1, 10, 300237) A life of vow is like marriage, a sacrament.
('50', 186, 1, 11, 300282) It is marriage with God indissoluble for all time.
('50', 186, 1, 12, 300333) Come let us marry Him.
('50', 186, 1, 13, 300356) Verb Sap.
('50', 186, 3, 14, 300366) From a photostat: G.N. 10081

('50', 188, 4, 9, 303093) 274. LETTER TO JAYAPRAKASH NARAYAN
('50', 188, 5, 10, 303128) YERAVDA MANDIR, November 1, 1930
('50', 188, 6, 11, 303161) JAYAPRAKASH, I have your letter.
('50', 188, 6, 12, 303194) I am glad.
('50', 188, 6, 13, 303205) You are entitled to write as you do.
('50', 188, 6, 14, 303242) Your grief moves me.
('50', 188, 6, 15, 303263) Your love for your mother 3 is commendable and becomes you.
('50', 188, 6, 16, 303323) I enclose a letter to G.D. Birla.
('50', 188, 6, 17, 303357) 4 Take it to him and see him.
('50', 188, 6, 18, 303387) However, I must caution you.
('50', 188, 6, 19, 303416) I myself have drunk deep from the fountain of motherly love.
('50', 188, 6, 20, 303477) I was devoted to my parents; I worshipped them.
('50', 188, 6, 21, 303525) And yet in your love for your mother I see attachment.
('50', 188, 6, 22, 303580) Your love should be informed with knowledge.Your mother has died in the body.
('50', 188, 6, 23, 303658) Her spirit has not perished.
('50', 188, 6, 24, 303687) The body had to perish one day.
('50', 188, 6, 25, 303719) Your love should now undergo a transformation.
('50', 188, 6, 26, 303766) Our true mother is the motherland.
('50', 188, 6, 27, 303801) Your filial love should be transformed into love of the motherland and to make it endure you should dedicate yourself to the service of the motherland.
('50', 188, 6, 28, 303953) You must not distress yourself that an expert doctor was not called.
('50', 188, 6, 29, 304022) Millions of mothers get no medical assistance.
('50', 188, 6, 30, 304069) And I cannot admit that they are thereby necessarily the losers.
('50', 188, 6, 31, 304134) Even the best of doctors cannot confer immortality on anyone.
('50', 188, 6, 32, 304196) Therefore, in my view you and everyone else should give expression to your filial love by dwelling on the virtues of the departed and emulating them and you should devote all your energies for the cause of the motherland.

('50', 189, 1, 5, 304876) But the death of your mother has created a new situation and reconsideration may be the duty.
('50', 189, 1, 6, 304970) However, if my advice does not appeal to you, you may use the letter to Ghanshyamdasji and earnestly try to earn a livelihood.

('50', 190, 1, 2, 306408) 276. LETTER TO RADHABEHN GANDHI
('50', 190, 2, 3, 306440) November 2, 1930
('50', 190, 3, 4, 306457) RADHIKA, I have your letter.
('50', 190, 3, 5, 306486) Read mine over and over and go on asking me about what you do not understand in it.
('50', 190, 3, 6, 306570) I preserve both my self respect and humility if, when someone kicks me and tries to force me to salute him, I suffer the kicks but do not get angry and wish well of the person kicking me, do not utter even one word in reply and still refuse to salute him.
('50', 190, 3, 7, 306826) Once a person kicked me and tried to force me to sit at his feet, but I said nothing to him, never wished him ill even in a dream, and yet refused to sit at his feet.
('50', 190, 3, 8, 306993) I believe I had preserved both self respect and humility.
('50', 190, 3, 9, 307051) When the incident took place, I was notat all conscious that I was being humble or anything of the sort.
('50', 190, 3, 10, 307156) I narrate it now only in order to explain my meaning.
('50', 190, 3, 11, 307210) You can think of many similar situations.
('50', 190, 3, 12, 307252) You may even recall some from your own life, and it would be very good indeed if one formed the habit, and learnt the art, of reflecting on such incidents in one’s own life rather than in another’s.
('50', 190, 3, 13, 307451) In doing so, one should not search for incidents in one’s life which show one’s own virtues.
('50', 190, 3, 14, 307544) Our virtues are for others to see.
('50', 190, 3, 15, 307579) We should try to discover our shortcomings.
('50', 190, 4, 16, 307623) Blessings from BAPU [PS.] It is also humility to see one’s own shortcomings.

('50', 199, 3, 9, 320637) We have discussed the Ashram observances, their necessity and the meaning of yajna.
('50', 199, 3, 10, 320721) I propose now to discuss the meaning of the book, as I have understood it, on which we meditate daily and from which we recite some portion every day so as to complete all the chapters in a week, the book which we have accepted as our spiritual lighthouse.
('50', 199, 3, 11, 320978) A letter which I had once received had suggested this to me, but Govindji’s letter received last week made me decide to take up the subject.
('50', 199, 3, 12, 321119) He says that he tries to read the Anasaktiyoga but finds it very difficult to understand.
('50', 199, 3, 13, 321209) Though I have tried to explain the meaning of the verses in a language which everyone can understand, a literal rendering is bound to present difficulties to the reader.
('50', 199, 3, 14, 321379) If the subject itself is difficult, how much can simplicity of language help?
('50', 199, 3, 15, 321457) I, therefore, intend here to present the subject itself in a manner easy to follow.
('50', 199, 3, 16, 321541) A book which we want to consult in every activity of our life and with whose help we try to solve all our spiritual problems—if we try again and again to understand the meaning of this book from all possible points of view and meditate over it constantly, we shall ultimately come to be filled with its spirit.
('50', 199, 3, 17, 321852) In all my spiritual difficulties I run to mother Gita and to this day she has never failed to comfort me.
('50', 199, 3, 18, 321958) It is, therefore, not impossible that otherswho seek similar comfort from her may, if they know what new light I get from it every day, receive further help or see some altogether new meaning in the work.

('50', 201, 2, 3, 323774) YERAVDA MANDIR, November 6, 1930

('50', 201, 3, 6, 323891) It gave all the trouble, you had, to Kaka.

('50', 201, 3, 10, 324111) I think 6 threads.
('50', 201, 3, 11, 324130) For the moving wheel the mal knot should be from the outside.
('50', 201, 3, 12, 324192) Neither need be too tight.
('50', 201, 3, 13, 324219) The wheel must move without any jerk.
('50', 201, 3, 14, 324257) It may be that the metal rings are not rigidly fixed in the wheels or the axles are not straight or in a straight line.

('50', 201, 3, 17, 324560) I suppose it is true about wheels as it is true about most things that what suits one does not therefore suit all others.
('50', 201, 3, 18, 324682) Experts have to adjust values of different types.
('50', 201, 3, 19, 324732) We workers must be satisfied with that which will give the maximum of work with the minimum of trouble.
('50', 201, 3, 20, 324836) If I had the requisite mechanical training or was a genius in the art, I should love to become an expert in carding and spinning and judging bows, wheels and taklis.
('50', 201, 3, 21, 325002) But I must treat it as a forbidden ambition, though I do not leave off the search.

('50', 201, 3, 25, 325404) I have now, therefore, only 42 bhajans to do.

('50', 201, 3, 27, 325525) I hope to finish before 42 days are out .

('50', 204, 1, 2, 329276) 296. LETTER TO BHAGWANJI PANDYA
('50', 204, 2, 3, 329308) YERAVDA MANDIR, November 7, 1930
('50', 204, 3, 4, 329341) BHAGWANJI, I have your letter.
('50', 204, 3, 5, 329372) You will realize truth more and more as you will stop observing what others do and concentrate on your work.
('50', 204, 3, 6, 329481) Nor should you plunge too much into thinking.
('50', 204, 3, 7, 329527) Of course one has to think up to a point.
('50', 204, 3, 8, 329569) After that one should depend only on faith.
('50', 204, 3, 9, 329613) The mind too like the body suffers from indigestion when overstuffed.
('50', 204, 3, 10, 329683) Like the body the mind too needs to be put at rest.
('50', 204, 3, 11, 329735) That is why there has been enjoined constant repetition of Ramanama and other mantras.
('50', 204, 3, 12, 329822) They instantly put the mind to rest.
('50', 204, 3, 13, 329859) Now the meaning: The higher and the lower [para and apara] means, so to say, the unmanifest and the manifest.
('50', 204, 3, 14, 329969) The Gita often discusses them.
('50', 204, 3, 15, 330000) Let us understand it briefly as the Lord (Ishwar) or Brahman or even Truth.
('50', 204, 3, 16, 330076) Self evident truth is the higher and the other realized by an individual is therefore finite: [i.e.,] lower.
('50', 204, 3, 17, 330185) A person who has a glimpse of (this aspect of) the Lord in His higher form is relieved from the good or bad fruit of his actions and all his problems and misgivings disappear.
('50', 204, 3, 18, 330361) The Gita II.
('50', 204, 3, 19, 330374) 59, viz., ‘the yearning too departs when he beholds the Supreme’ also conveys the same sense.
('50', 204, 3, 20, 330468) A person who becomes engrossed in discharging whatever duty naturally comes to his lot, has as good as realized the para 1 and this ought to put an end to his problems.
('50', 204, 3, 21, 330637) He who cannot experience it has not [yet] identified himself with his duty.
('50', 204, 3, 22, 330713) I have here tried to put it across so that you may understand it fully, but do ask me if you cannot, in spite of this.
('50', 204, 4, 23, 330832) Blessings from BAPU
('50', 204, 5, 24, 330852) From a copy of the Gujarati: C.W. 329. Courtesy: Bhagwanji Purushottam Pandya
('50', 204, 6, 25, 330930) 1 The source has apara which is obviously a slip.

('50', 223, 1, 2, 356705) 327. LETTER TO C. F. ANDREWS

('50', 234, 1, 2, 376954) that she is weak, she can be free this very day.
('50', 234, 1, 3, 377003) The really strong are not those who are strong in body.
('50', 234, 1, 4, 377059) Ravana, who was a demon, that is, had physical strength, was helpless before the seemingly weak Sita.
('50', 234, 1, 5, 377161) I am sure you remember the story.
('50', 234, 1, 6, 377195) Sita was under the protection of a boon to the effect that anyone who cast an evil glance at her would be instantly burnt to ashes.
('50', 234, 1, 7, 377327) Ravana knew this and that is why, though he carried her away, he could not touch her person with impure thoughts.
('50', 234, 1, 8, 377441) He had to entreat Sita to let him embrace her.
('50', 234, 1, 9, 377488) He threatened her time and again in the hope that she might yield; but unless she yielded of her own free will he was, in spite of his strength, as helpless as a goat.

('50', 234, 1, 13, 377782) Every woman who has inviolable purity of character enjoys the same boon as Sita did.

('50', 244, 3, 6, 391939) on Wednesday, that is, yesterday.
('50', 244, 3, 7, 391973) The devotee “renounces all undertakings”.
('50', 244, 3, 8, 392015) 1 This means the devotee will not draw up schemes of future expansion.
('50', 244, 3, 9, 392086) For example, if a merchant who deals in cloth now has any plans of selling firewood as well in the future, or if he, having one shop only, thinks of opening five more shops, that would be arambha (undertaking) on his part, and the devotee will have none of it.
('50', 244, 3, 10, 392347) This principle is applicable to service of the nation as well.
('50', 244, 3, 11, 392410) For instance, a worker in the khadi department today will not take up cow keeping tomorrow, agriculture the day after and medical aid on the fourth day.
('50', 244, 3, 12, 392563) He will do his best in whatever has come to him.
('50', 244, 3, 13, 392612) When I am free from egoism, nothing remains for me to do.
('50', 244, 3, 14, 392670) ‘The Lord has bound me with a cotton thread; I am His, no matter where He leads me.
('50', 244, 3, 15, 392754) I have been stabbed with the dagger of love.’ A devotee’s every activity is planned by God.
('50', 244, 3, 16, 392846) It comes to him as in the natural course of things.
('50', 244, 3, 17, 392898) He therefore rests content with,‘this, that or anything else’ (ÿŸ ∑§ŸÁøÃ˜Ô |) This is the meaning of ‘reonouncing all undertakings’.
('50', 244, 3, 18, 393033) The devotee does not cease to work; indeed he is nothing if not a worker.
('50', 244, 3, 19, 393107) He only ceases to think needless thoughts about his work.
('50', 244, 3, 20, 393165) It is these that he hat to renounce.
('50', 244, 3, 21, 393202) ‘This has been acquired by me today; that purpose I shall gain tomorrow’ 2 —this is the opposite of ‘renouncing undertakings’.
('50', 244, 3, 22, 393329) I think this answers your question fully.
('50', 244, 3, 23, 393371) Ask me if anything is left out.
('50', 244, 3, 24, 393403) Keep this portion with the discussion which is proceeding.
('50', 244, 3, 25, 393462) If, along with the new pair of sandals, you have not sent a piece of leather for repairing the soles, and if you can get such a piece and send it, with someone who may be coming on a visit here, please do send it, or send it by sample post provided it does not cost much, so that I can use when necessary even the worn out sandals.

('50', 246, 1, 24, 397721) To spin by way of yajna and to take up spinning as labour in order merely to add that much to one’s earning are twodifferent things.
('50', 246, 1, 25, 397854) In yajna, the actual work, though extremely important, is of secondary value.
('50', 246, 1, 26, 397932) In spinning undertaken as labour, the actual work is all that matters.

('50', 246, 1, 29, 398209) That is, yajna completely fulfils one’s cherished desires.
('50', 246, 1, 30, 398268) In performing such a yajna, one must lose oneself in one’s work.

('50', 246, 1, 33, 398564) He would not even think about anything else when working.

('50', 247, 2, 22, 401240) Those who are interested in the reading will not grudge the extra 6_ minutes.

('50', 251, 1, 2, 406435) 362. LETTER TO PYARE LAL GOVIL 1
('50', 251, 2, 3, 406468) YERAVDA CENTRAL PRISON, November 19, 1930
('50', 251, 3, 4, 406510) DEAR FRIEND, Your touching letter of 28th ultimo has been given to me.
('50', 251, 3, 5, 406581) My sympathy goes out to you in your affliction and I should be glad indeed if this letter brings you any comfort.
('50', 251, 3, 6, 406695) In my opinion you are in no way to blame.
('50', 251, 3, 7, 406737) Having got the lady doctor you were quite right in trusting her.
('50', 251, 3, 8, 406802) I do not believe in constant change of doctors and hakims.
('50', 251, 3, 9, 406861) We must trust those whom we get to tell us when they need assistance or are in doubt as to their diagnosis.
('50', 251, 3, 10, 406969) Sometimes it may be found that the trust was misplaced.
('50', 251, 3, 11, 407025) But these are risks and chances of life which we must take always.
('50', 251, 3, 12, 407092) I hope therefore that you will not worry yourself over what you consider was your negligence.
('50', 251, 3, 13, 407186) This much you know yourself that you did not wilfully neglect anything.
('50', 251, 3, 14, 407258) More no man can do.
('50', 251, 4, 15, 407278) 1 This was in reply to a letter dated October 28, 1930 from Pyare Lal Govil, Sub Judge, Muzaffarnagar, U.P. He had lost his parents some 15 to 20 years ago and his only sister 16 years before writing.
('50', 251, 4, 16, 407479) Narrating the circumstances of the death of his only child, a 24 year old daughter, following a delivery, he wrote that the sepsis from which she was suffering could not be diagnosed in time.
('50', 251, 4, 17, 407671) He blamed himself for “culpable mistakes” resulting in her death.
('50', 251, 4, 18, 407737) He further wrote: “If God has made destinies and every thing happens as has been fixed beforehand then there is no use in praying for mercy.
('50', 251, 4, 19, 407878) If He is powerless then He need not be approached.
('50', 251, 4, 20, 407929) The following shankas [doubts] arise: 1. What prayashchitta should I perform to wash off this sin of utter care lessness?
('50', 251, 4, 21, 408051) 2. How to give rest to her soul?
('50', 251, 4, 22, 408084) 3. Could she have not been saved if correct and timely help had been given?
('50', 251, 4, 23, 408160) 4. Is God powerless in changing the course of destinies?
('50', 251, 4, 24, 408217) If so then there is no use in prayer, nor in taking medicines nor in asking for medical help, or in making any efforts that way.
('50', 251, 4, 25, 408346) 5. Does a soul wander here and there for any length of time after departing from this body?
('50', 251, 4, 26, 408438) 6. How should and can I know that she has taken birth anywhere else?
('50', 251, 4, 27, 408507) 7. The idea that I have been very careless haunts me every moment, although I can swear that I did not know that I was making any mistake when I made them, else I would have never made them.
('50', 251, 4, 28, 408698) I do not know what had become of my discretion and sense.
('50', 251, 4, 29, 408756) Now I want nothing but I wish to know if I can in any way help her soul to get rest and stay in Heaven.
('50', 251, 4, 30, 408860) If so what should I do?
('50', 251, 4, 31, 408884) Very kindly give your ashirvad for the departed soul.”
('50', 252, 0, 1, 408939) VOL.50 : 23 AUGUST, 1930 6 JANUARY, 1931 253
('50', 252, 1, 2, 408984) Now for the answers to your questions: (1) No prayashchitta is needed because in my opinion there was no carelessness on your part.
('50', 252, 1, 3, 409116) (2) No one can give rest to another soul.
('50', 252, 1, 4, 409158) Her rest will come from herself.
('50', 252, 1, 5, 409191) (3) It is impossible to say what would have happened if other assistance had been procured.
('50', 252, 1, 6, 409283) In spite of the ablest expert help kings have to die.
('50', 252, 1, 7, 409337) (4) There ought not to be much sorrow or fuss over an inevitable event.
('50', 252, 1, 8, 409409) Death is the lot of every created thing, nor need it be considered as a calamity.
('50', 252, 1, 9, 409491) Death is in reality a deliverance.
('50', 252, 1, 10, 409526) (5) What the soul does after discarding a body is in each case surmise but it is a certainty that the soul does not perish with the body.
('50', 252, 1, 11, 409664) Let us trust the laws of God or nature for the rest.
('50', 252, 1, 12, 409717) (6) States before birth and after death are invisible as the Gita affirms and experience confirms.
('50', 252, 1, 13, 409816) But we can infer from our present state that the condition after death is at least likely to be a second, though modified, edition of the present.
('50', 252, 1, 14, 409963) (7) We the survivors can certainly help the departed dear ones by wearing into our own lives all that was good in them.
('50', 252, 1, 15, 410083) For if they know anything of what happens here they must be consoled by the knowledge that we are treasuring their memories by adopting what was best in them.
('50', 252, 2, 16, 410242) Yours sincerely,
('50', 252, 3, 17, 410259) M. K. GANDHI [PS.] One question has been omitted by oversight.
('50', 252, 3, 18, 410322) God is never powerless.
('50', 252, 3, 19, 410346) But His laws are immutable.
('50', 252, 3, 20, 410374) We do not know them.
('50', 252, 3, 21, 410395) Nor do we know His will at a given moment.
('50', 252, 3, 22, 410438) Therefore we adopt within bounds such remedies as may commend themselves to us.
('50', 252, 3, 23, 410518) Prayer is to the God within.
('50', 252, 3, 24, 410547) It does not provoke God to change His will but it enables us to know His will which is everything.

('50', 256, 4, 6, 416210) I think my memory is as weak as yours, but this is the method I followed, and still follow, for memorizing whatever I did, or do when I get any time for that, and I have no doubt that it is the best one.
('50', 256, 4, 7, 416414) We should first try and understand the meaning of what we wish to memorize and the relations of the different parts to each other.
('50', 256, 4, 8, 416545) After we have done this, all that remains to do is to commit to memory the poet’s words expressing that meaning and those relations.
('50', 256, 4, 9, 416678) This is easy to do.
('50', 256, 4, 10, 416698) Try this method and memorize Chapter XII.
('50', 256, 4, 11, 416740) Arjuna asks: “As between one who worships in this manner and another who worships the Unmanifest, who is superior?” Reflect over the reply to this question and then try to memorize the verses.
('50', 256, 4, 12, 416933) This is interesting, involves no waste of energy and, because we have faith, the meaning sinks in our heart while we try to memorize the verses.

('50', 259, 1, 4, 420900) Iwould speak to you about the Bihar wheel.
('50', 259, 1, 5, 420943) The alteration you have made doesn’t seem to me to have added to the utility of the wheel.
('50', 259, 1, 6, 421034) The original length of the platform is the ideal length.
('50', 259, 1, 7, 421091) The length in the “improved” machine is too much for drawing the thread away from you and too little for drawing it towards you.
('50', 259, 1, 8, 421220) The original holders may admit of a change.
('50', 259, 1, 9, 421264) I am trying the coir holders in the Gandiv and they have worked exceedingly well.
('50', 259, 1, 10, 421346) In the coir holders the spindle moves in the rough and smooth convex surface of the coir twine.
('50', 259, 1, 11, 421442) Hence it moves with the minimum of friction.
('50', 259, 1, 12, 421487) In the Bihar holders the spindle moves lazily on 1/8th inch flat surface.
('50', 259, 1, 13, 421561) Hence there is avoidable friction.
('50', 259, 1, 14, 421596) The coir holders undoubtedly last long, take no time to make and hold oil better.
('50', 259, 1, 15, 421678) Coir twine is available anywhere.
('50', 259, 1, 16, 421712) It can be picked from waste.
('50', 259, 1, 17, 421741) These hints are for you to note and follow out where you have leisure.

('50', 270, 2, 11, 440843) I call this chapter the key to an understanding of the Gita, and the gist of it is that life is given us for service and not for enjoyment.
('50', 270, 2, 12, 440983) We have therefore to impart a sacrificial character to our lives.

('50', 278, 7, 13, 454530) We may not refuse work when it is demanded of us according to rules.
('50', 278, 7, 14, 454599) We should rather be anxious to do as much work as we can and that too as efficiently as we are capable of.

('50', 280, 1, 2, 458132) 400. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK
('50', 280, 2, 3, 458164) YERAVDA MANDIR, Night, November 30, 1930
('50', 280, 3, 4, 458205) PREMA, I was very happy to read your letter.
('50', 280, 3, 5, 458250) It is two days now since you broke your fast.
('50', 280, 3, 6, 458296) By the time you get this letter, you will have forgotten all about the fast and will be enjoying new youth.
('50', 280, 3, 7, 458404) If you do not have that experience, I would not regard the fast as a complete success.
('50', 280, 3, 8, 458491) I expect that you will describe the result of your fast in detail.
('50', 280, 3, 9, 458558) Your experience should be a guide to others.
('50', 280, 3, 10, 458603) You know, of course, how to return to normal diet gradually after the fast is over.
('50', 280, 3, 11, 458687) You will feel very hungry immediately after a fast, but you should certainly not eat as much as the stomach demands.
('50', 280, 3, 12, 458804) You should gradually increase the quantity of milk and curds, and eat nothing between the meals.
('50', 280, 3, 13, 458901) You may of course eat juicy fruits.
('50', 280, 3, 14, 458937) I hope you do not count expense in that regard.

('50', 282, 1, 2, 462040) 402. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('50', 282, 2, 3, 462064) November 29/December 1, 1930
('50', 282, 3, 4, 462093) MIRA, This is time after the morning prayer 29 11 1930. It is fairly cold.
('50', 282, 3, 5, 462168) But I do a little writing after the prayer and before walking out on the bugle of 5.30. I am glad you were better when you wrote your letter.
('50', 282, 3, 6, 462310) We can only learn really in everything as in the matter of health keeping by making repeated mistakes and profiting by them.
('50', 282, 3, 7, 462435) This is an introduction to my confession rather than a warning to you.
('50', 282, 3, 8, 462506) Last Thursday I suddenly developed a bad stomachache.
('50', 282, 3, 9, 462560) I could have avoided it but stupidly did not.
('50', 282, 3, 10, 462606) As you know I have been lately living on curds.
('50', 282, 3, 11, 462654) They agreed very well though the bowels could be moved only by the enema.
('50', 282, 3, 12, 462728) But as you saw the weight was going up and I was otherwise fit.
('50', 282, 3, 13, 462792) So I continued the curds and then too the thick part.
('50', 282, 3, 14, 462846) That induced further constipation despite the enema.
('50', 282, 3, 15, 462899) That was sufficient warning to stop at least curds or better still all food for a day.
('50', 282, 3, 16, 462986) I would not and suffered for the day.
('50', 282, 3, 17, 463024) I voluntarily brought out what I had eaten and in a few hours the pain subsided.
('50', 282, 3, 18, 463105) Nothing but raisin water the next day and I was quite fit though at once I lost 3 lb.
('50', 282, 3, 19, 463191) in weight.
('50', 282, 3, 20, 463202) It is ever thus with me.
('50', 282, 3, 21, 463227) My weight beyond 95 is evidently an uncertain quantity probably made up of poisonous matter.
('50', 282, 3, 22, 463320) I determined too to get rid of the constipation if it was at all possible, so I have continued the stopping of curds.
('50', 282, 3, 23, 463438) (Here is the bugle and I stop for the time being).
('50', 282, 3, 24, 463489) To resume at 8 p.m.
('50', 282, 3, 25, 463509) And I am now taking cooked leaves and tomatoes and dates or raisins.
('50', 282, 3, 26, 463578) The bowels have moved naturally, strength has been maintained and the weight has suffered no further reduction.
('50', 282, 3, 27, 463690) Yesterday I added sweet potatoes and today 12 almonds.
('50', 282, 3, 28, 463745) No one need be alarmed at this change.
('50', 282, 3, 29, 463784) If I feel weak or lose weight steadily, I shall at once revert to milk and shall feel all the better for the milk fast.
('50', 282, 3, 30, 463904) If on the other hand the change agrees it will be a source of additional joy.
('50', 282, 3, 31, 463982) Therefore you should all rejoice over the change.
('50', 282, 3, 32, 464032) If it works, it is well.
('50', 282, 3, 33, 464057) It is well also if it does not.
('50', 282, 3, 34, 464089) I shall take no risks.

('50', 283, 1, 18, 465338) The golden rule is not to fret if things go contrary to one’s wishes and to yield where resistance is useless or likely to be misunderstood, where there is no principle at stake and where in an organization responsibility is not solely one’s own.
('50', 283, 1, 19, 465585) The virtue of charity comes into play only when one comes in contact with a variety of opinion and conduct.
('50', 283, 1, 20, 465693) Strict and even harsh with ourselves, charitable and even lax with regard to others.
('50', 283, 1, 21, 465778) In the end, we find that we are neither strict regarding ourselves nor lax regarding others.
('50', 283, 1, 22, 465871) The fact is we do not as readily observe our own blemishes as we are to detect those of others.
('50', 283, 1, 23, 465967) Hence the terrible truth “Pluck the beam out of thine own eyes before you remove the mote from thy neighbour’s” or Burns’s (Is it not?) “O that we could see ourselves as others see us.” In practice I have found that it is best to search about ourselves and to assume the truth of friends’ criticism of ourselves and to take them in the first instance at their word when they disown guilt or defect.

('50', 289, 3, 5, 475355) I was glad to learn that your mother and others had arrived.
('50', 289, 3, 6, 475416) If you take your meals with your mother with Narandas’s consent, I should not object.
('50', 289, 3, 7, 475502) However, there is certainly a moral flaw in what you are doing.
('50', 289, 3, 8, 475566) You ought to make it clear to Mother that the life which you two live is different from normal family life.
('50', 289, 3, 9, 475674) Of course the financial aspect of the matter creates some difficulty.
('50', 289, 3, 10, 475744) But I have stated here only the ideal.
('50', 289, 3, 11, 475783) Do not take my words to mean that you ought to take your meals in the common kitchen, as we cannot always live up to an ideal and sometimes in actual practice we have to compromise it in order that we may not be forced to give it up altogether.
('50', 289, 3, 12, 476028) As for your relations with Father, strictness is necessary.
('50', 289, 3, 13, 476088) You should tell him in the plainest language that he should give up hopes of your taking up a job or a profession and earning money.
('50', 289, 3, 14, 476221) By telling him this, you will serve him, for, as long as there is the slightest hope, he will continue complaining to you, but will cease doing so or rather the complaining will cease of itself, when he has given up the hope.
('50', 289, 3, 15, 476447) This is human nature.
('50', 289, 3, 16, 476469) When hope is entirely gone, despair itself turns into a sort of consolation.
('50', 289, 3, 17, 476546) There are here several prisoners serving life sentences, who have no hope of being released and, therefore, live cheerfully.
('50', 289, 3, 18, 476671) Those whose position is uncertain, like mine, suffer.
('50', 289, 3, 19, 476725) They keep on hoping from day to day that they would soon be released.
('50', 289, 3, 20, 476795) In other words, the cause of the pain in your relationship with Father is in your own mind.
('50', 289, 3, 21, 476887) If you have understood your dharma clearly you should not so much as give a thought to Father’s complaining.
('50', 289, 3, 22, 476996) To borrow money from friends to help Father to pay his debts and relieve his burden to that extent is not a good policy.
('50', 289, 3, 23, 477117) It would be better not to receive such private benefits from one’s friends.
('50', 289, 3, 24, 477193) Here again, I have merely stated the ideal.
('50', 289, 3, 25, 477237) It may be advisable, in case of necessity, to borrow money from Mahavir Prasad and others if your relationswith them are intimate.
('50', 289, 3, 26, 477368) Solve all these problems with the master key of non attachment.

('50', 296, 8, 10, 484949) December 6, 1930
('50', 296, 9, 11, 484966) BHAGWANJI, I have your letter.
('50', 296, 9, 12, 484997) Your interpretation of the term abhyasa is correct, as also of chittavrittinirodha.
('50', 296, 9, 13, 485081) Dhyana=Upasana, i.e., ulti mately it could mean faithfully observing one’s own dharma.
('50', 296, 9, 14, 485168) In my view here the word dhyana is used in a narrower sense.
('50', 296, 9, 15, 485229) Dhyana refers to our silent sittings at the time of our worship and prayers.
('50', 296, 9, 16, 485306) This brings about a [sense of] dedication to the Lord, which in its turn gives rise to a disinterested attitude.
('50', 296, 9, 17, 485419) No social service is possible without self purification, which again develops in the course of social service.
('50', 296, 9, 18, 485530) It is all right therefore that doubts arise in your mind but you should not fall into their currents.
('50', 296, 9, 19, 485632) If they are resolved so much the better; if not you should have faith that they would be solved as you go on serving.

('50', 298, 0, 1, 487485) VOL.50 : 23 AUGUST, 1930 5 JANUARY, 1931 299
('50', 298, 1, 2, 487530) flesh eating, since we are accustomed from birth to do without it.
('50', 298, 1, 3, 487597) But there may be great merit in the self denial of a person who was a habitual meateater but has given up eating it now, though he may repeatedly break his vow.
('50', 298, 1, 4, 487758) Hence the right thing is that we ourselves should do the best we can to follow a rule perfectly, and be satisfied with what others can do.

('50', 298, 7, 22, 488940) It is not necessary to rewrite the whole of your book.
('50', 298, 7, 23, 488995) How much cotton should I hold out to the string at a time and in how many pulls should it get carded?

('50', 298, 7, 29, 489421) The left hand should be used only for raising and lowering the carding bow and it is moved forwards and backwards by the action of the rod; isn’t that what you mean?

('50', 311, 1, 2, 509693) 439 LETTER TO JAYAPRAKASH NARAYAN
('50', 311, 2, 3, 509727) December 11, 1930
('50', 311, 3, 4, 509745) JAYAPRAKASH, I have your beautiful letter.
('50', 311, 3, 5, 509788) What you have thought about Father is only right.
('50', 311, 3, 6, 509838) I shall say nothing more about it.
('50', 311, 3, 7, 509873) I hope you were successful with Ghanshyamdas.
('50', 311, 3, 8, 509919) As regards the motherland being considered as your mother there is a flaw in your thought.
('50', 311, 3, 9, 510010) Just as loving one’s mother does not mean that one should not love another’s mother, so also loving one’s motherland does not mean hating other countries.
('50', 311, 3, 10, 510165) Where there is no love for the motherland love of the world is an illusion.
('50', 311, 3, 11, 510241) And since the motherland has a greater right over us, being proud of the motherland without any ill will for other countries is only proper.
('50', 311, 3, 12, 510382) I cannot directly care for the children of the whole world.
('50', 311, 3, 13, 510442) But if I care lovingly for the children who are in my keeping I shall to that extent be doing service to the children of the world.
('50', 311, 3, 14, 510574) The case of the motherland is exactly similar.
('50', 311, 3, 15, 510621) After all it does matter in which land and in which atmosphere we are born.
('50', 311, 3, 16, 510697) Ahimsa has its origin in this thought.
('50', 311, 3, 17, 510736) In so far as ahimsa means universal love it can have direct application in our serving the creatures who are nearest us.
('50', 311, 3, 18, 510857) I hope you will now take Prabhavati to the Ashram.
('50', 311, 4, 19, 510908) Blessings from
('50', 311, 6, 20, 510923) From the Hindi original: Jayaprakash Narayan Papers.

('50', 311, 8, 23, 511052) December 12, 1930
('50', 311, 9, 24, 511070) PRABHUDAS, If one does not like a particular name, he should himself suggest a better one.

('50', 312, 1, 2, 511581) who runs an ashram is not different from others.
('50', 312, 1, 3, 511630) Any place where the rules of an ashram are followed, is like an ashram.
('50', 312, 1, 4, 511702) You are a society of eight persons.
('50', 312, 1, 5, 511738) You have with you there the Gita, the Ramayana and the spinning wheel.
('50', 312, 1, 6, 511809) What more do you want?
('50', 312, 1, 7, 511832) For running the ashram, it is necessary to have some persons.
('50', 312, 1, 8, 511894) Just take it that you three are the ones sent there for the purpose.
('50', 312, 1, 9, 511963) Devotion of Tulsidas was the devotion of the future generation.

('50', 312, 1, 14, 512292) “I am the Creator of all the three qualities.” Wherever we find deceit and fault in God, we need not accept Tulsidas’s saying that God has no faults and that we should not do as He does.
('50', 312, 1, 15, 512479) We have to observe the rules of proper conduct.
('50', 312, 1, 16, 512527) We cannot abide by the text of the inimitable book of Tulsidas, but have to abide by its inner meaning.
('50', 312, 1, 17, 512631) What does not appeal to us should be set aside.
('50', 312, 1, 18, 512679) One experiences the mind’s quality of forgetfulness every minute.

('50', 313, 0, 1, 513468) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('50', 313, 1, 2, 513510) 442. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('50', 313, 2, 3, 513534) December 13, 1930
('50', 313, 3, 4, 513552) MIRA, Your p.c.
('50', 313, 3, 5, 513568) was duly received.
('50', 313, 3, 6, 513587) The absence of any further news from you, I take to mean perfect restoration.
('50', 313, 3, 7, 513665) After each illness you are soon well, because the treatment followed is natural, but every sickness leaves behind it a legacy of weakness unless the system is allowed full rest and the mind relieved of tension.
('50', 313, 3, 8, 513876) I suppose the mental control is the most difficult.
('50', 313, 3, 9, 513928) For this the sovereign remedy is the application of the Gita.
('50', 313, 3, 10, 513990) Each time mind suffers a shock, there is failure in application.
('50', 313, 3, 11, 514055) Let good news as well as bad pass over you like water over a duck’s back.
('50', 313, 3, 12, 514129) When we hear any, our duty is merely to find out whether any action is necessary and if it is, to do it as an instrument in the hands of Nature without being affected by or attached to the result.
('50', 313, 3, 13, 514326) This detachment appears a scientific necessity when we remember that in bringing about a result more than one instrument is employed.
('50', 313, 3, 14, 514460) Who shall dare say ‘I have done it’[?] I know you know all this.
('50', 313, 3, 15, 514525) Nevertheless, I drive the truth home, so that from the brain it may percolate to the heart.
('50', 313, 3, 16, 514617) So long as it remains in the brain only, it is a dead weight on it.
('50', 313, 3, 17, 514685) Any truth received by the brain must immediately be sent down to the heart.
('50', 313, 3, 18, 514761) When it is not, it suffers abortion and then it lies on the brain as so much poisonous matter.
('50', 313, 3, 19, 514856) What poisons the brain poisons the whole system.
('50', 313, 3, 20, 514905) Hence the necessity of using the brain as it should be merely as a transmitting station.
('50', 313, 3, 21, 514994) Whatever is there received is either transmitted to the heart for immediate action or it is rejected there and then as being unfit for transmission.
('50', 313, 3, 22, 515143) Failure of the brain to perform this function properly is the cause of almost all the ills that flesh is heir to as also for mental exhaustion.
('50', 313, 3, 23, 515287) If the brain simply performed its function, there need never be any brain fag.
('50', 313, 3, 24, 515366) So whenever we suffer from illness generally there is not only a dietetic error but there is also failure on the part of the brain to function properly.
('50', 313, 3, 25, 515519) The author of the Gita evidently saw this and gave the world the sovereign remedy in the clearest possible language.
('50', 313, 3, 26, 515636) Whenever therefore anything preys upon your mind, you should meditate on the central teaching of the Gita and throw off the burden.
('50', 313, 3, 27, 515768) Let us hope there never will be a recurrence of the terrible constipation.
('50', 314, 0, 1, 515843) VOL.50 : 23 AUGUST, 1930 5 JANUARY, 1931 315
('50', 314, 1, 2, 515888) As to Kumarappa if you have enough charity and goodwill forward to him all the criticism you receive leaving the result to take care of itself.
('50', 314, 1, 3, 516032) It is a duty you owe to him to let him have the criticisms.
('50', 314, 1, 4, 516092) You may now use Kaka too for the purpose of sending your messages.
('50', 314, 1, 5, 516159) For me the milkless experiment continues as yet without any bad result.
('50', 314, 1, 6, 516231) The weight has suffered a further decrease of 3 Ib.
('50', 314, 1, 7, 516283) but the vitality remains.
('50', 314, 1, 8, 516309) One cause of the decrease in weight is that I am most cautious about increasing the quantity of cereals and almonds I take.
('50', 314, 1, 9, 516433) Almonds remain at 3 tolas and bajri and juwari bhakhari a quarter, i.e., about 2 tolas each time, i.e., at 11 and 5. I may soon increase the weight.
('50', 314, 1, 10, 516582) Anyway the condition of the bowels is extraordinarily good.
('50', 314, 1, 11, 516642) I quite agree with you that the enema as a habit is a bad thing and should be got rid of, if at all possible.
('50', 314, 1, 12, 516752) It has been possible with the dropping of milk as it had become when, on going to Wardha, you will recall, I had dropped milk.
('50', 314, 1, 13, 516879) Indeed but for my folly in hastily following Gopalrao I might still have been flourishing on the diet I had then adopted.
('50', 314, 1, 14, 517001) The present diet is a slight modification of the Wardha one.
('50', 314, 1, 15, 517062) Whenever you are ill, you will not hesitate to write to me at once without waiting for the weekly letter day.
('50', 314, 3, 16, 517172) From a photostat: C.W. 9283. Courtesy: Mirabehn

('50', 316, 1, 2, 519183) 447. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK
('50', 316, 2, 3, 519215) December 14, 1930
('50', 316, 3, 4, 519233) PREMA, I have your letter.
('50', 316, 3, 5, 519260) I understand what you say about punishing children.
('50', 316, 3, 6, 519312) Your argument is an old one.
('50', 316, 3, 7, 519341) It is a vicious circle.
('50', 316, 3, 8, 519365) Punishment did you good and so you think you should punish the children.
('50', 316, 3, 9, 519438) When the children grow up, they will do the same.
('50', 316, 3, 10, 519488) This is exactly the argument by which people justify their faith in violence.
('50', 316, 3, 11, 519566) It is our aim to rise above this misleading experience.
('50', 316, 3, 12, 519622) I admit that that requires patience.
('50', 316, 3, 13, 519659) We have come together in the Ashram to cultivate that patience.
('50', 316, 3, 14, 519723) Our aim is not just to impart education to children or teach them discipline, but to build character in them.
('50', 316, 3, 15, 519833) Education, discipline, etc., are means to that end.
('50', 316, 3, 16, 519885) If the result of building character in them is that education and discipline .are neglected, let that be so.
('50', 316, 3, 17, 519994) I understand your argument, though.
('50', 316, 3, 18, 520030) I also see that there is no ill will behind your use of the rod.
('50', 316, 3, 19, 520095) But there are certainly anger and impatience behind them.
('50', 316, 3, 20, 520153) May I make a suggestion?
('50', 316, 3, 21, 520178) Call a meeting of the children.
('50', 316, 3, 22, 520210) If any of them say, ‘You may punish us, and in this manner, if we play mischief or disobey you’, you may punish them in the manner which they suggest.
('50', 316, 3, 23, 520361) You should not punish those who do not want youto punish them.
('50', 316, 3, 24, 520424) If you try this method, you will see that you do not need to punish them.
('50', 316, 3, 25, 520498) You should keep up this discussion.
('50', 316, 3, 26, 520534) Do not give up arguing out of impatience or despair.
('50', 316, 3, 27, 520587) Till your reason is convinced of what I say, you should follow your own path.
('50', 316, 3, 28, 520665) I know that you are dedicated to truth and, therefore, I am sure that you will realize the truth ultimately.
('50', 316, 3, 29, 520774) Your diet seems to be all right.
('50', 316, 3, 30, 520807) You did not describe your visit to Rajkot.
('50', 316, 4, 31, 520850) Blessings from

('50', 319, 1, 2, 523145) 453. LETTER TO KASHINATH TRIVEDI
('50', 319, 2, 3, 523178) YERAVDA MANDIR, December 14, 1930
('50', 319, 3, 4, 523212) KASHINATH, I got your letter.
('50', 319, 3, 5, 523242) I have already replied to Kalavati.
('50', 319, 3, 6, 523278) The treatment being given to Mother seems to be all right.
('50', 319, 3, 7, 523337) There is no doubt that constipation is the root cause of many diseases.
('50', 319, 3, 8, 523409) I will describe for your information the experiment I am making at present, which has succeeded in curing my constipation at least.
('50', 319, 3, 9, 523541) For two or three days I took boiled leafy vegetables, together with which I had also boiled unripe tomatoes.
('50', 319, 3, 10, 523650) That by itself cured the constipation.
('50', 319, 3, 11, 523689) Then I started adding crushed almonds, gradually increasing the quantity to three tolas and now I have been taking a few bhakharis made of jowar and bajra flour.
('50', 319, 3, 12, 523851) This seems to keep up my strength.
('50', 319, 3, 13, 523886) Of course I can say nothing definitely.
('50', 319, 3, 14, 523926) I can do that if I can go on like this for two or three months.
('50', 319, 3, 15, 523990) Anyone who wishes to follow my example should do so with great care.
('50', 319, 3, 16, 524059) Both Santok and Radha know about the two types of bath described in Kuhne’s book.
('50', 319, 3, 17, 524141) They should prove very beneficial for Kalavati.
('50', 319, 3, 18, 524189) We do not have a copy of the book 1 on mouth hygiene.
('50', 319, 3, 19, 524243) Convey my compliments to Dr. Sarjuprasadji.
('50', 319, 3, 20, 524287) I wish him success in his work.
('50', 319, 3, 21, 524319) How do I deserve any blessing for the low prices of grain?
('50', 319, 3, 22, 524378) Wouldn’t the cultivators, for their part, curse me?
('50', 319, 3, 23, 524430) There are several reasons for the prevailing low prices.
('50', 319, 3, 24, 524487) As far as I am concerned, I see no objection to making extracts from my letters provided they are taken with Narandas’s consent.
('50', 319, 3, 25, 524616) Pyarelal is happy and cheerful.
('50', 319, 3, 26, 524648) He has two editions of the Ramayana with him, and he is not therefore, anxious to have other books now.
('50', 319, 3, 27, 524752) After coming here, he had perforce to stop his reading.
('50', 319, 4, 28, 524808) Blessings from

('50', 321, 8, 14, 526461) December 15, 1930
('50', 321, 9, 15, 526479) PRABHAVATI, From Jayaprakash’s letter, it seems you must be in the Ashram now.
('50', 321, 9, 16, 526558) It has been arranged now that letters from you should be handed over to me as soon as they are received.
('50', 321, 9, 17, 526663) But I got no postcard or letter either today or yesterday.
('50', 321, 9, 18, 526722) If you have still not gone over to the Ashram, do so immediately.
('50', 321, 9, 19, 526788) Even after you have gone there, you should write to me daily for some time.
('50', 321, 9, 20, 526864) Your fainting fits must stop, and I think they will in the Ashram.
('50', 321, 9, 21, 526931) If you require fruit, etc., don’t hesitate to ask for it.
('50', 321, 9, 22, 526989) And don’t plunge into work immediately.
('50', 321, 9, 23, 527029) You have done enough work in the Ashram in the past, and hence you should take complete rest now.
('50', 321, 9, 24, 527127) Don’t burden your mind with worries.
('50', 321, 9, 25, 527164) Everything will happen as God wills it.
('50', 321, 9, 26, 527204) Meditate over the hymn Premal Jyoti 2.

('50', 322, 4, 4, 527651) Early in the morning I call to mind that Being which is felt in the heart, which is sat (the eternal), chit (knowledge) and sukham (bliss), which is the state reached by perfect men and which is the super state.

('50', 322, 7, 10, 528378) 7 5 1930
('50', 322, 8, 11, 528387) 1 Ashram Bhajanavali is a collection of devotional songs which formed part of the morning and evening prayers at Gandhiji’s ashrams.
('50', 322, 8, 12, 528520) They were in various languages and taken from various sources, some of them obscure, but all fairly popular in Hindu religious tradition.
('50', 322, 8, 13, 528658) Gandhiji rendered these into English for Mirabehn’s benefit, in the first place, during his imprisonment in Yeravda Central Prison.
('50', 322, 8, 14, 528790) The work of translation was begun on May 6, 1930 and the last hymn was translated on December 15. In 1934 George Allen & Unwin Ltd.
('50', 322, 8, 15, 528922) brought out an adaptation of the work by John S. Hoyland.
('50', 322, 8, 16, 528980) (For Gandhiji’s permission for its publication, vide “Letter to J. S. Hoyland”, 15 12 1933.) But in order to make the poems acceptable to English readers, Hoyland omitted a great deal, “chiefly Indian names and symbolism” but also much else so that at places it is difficult to recognize the original in the adaptation.
('50', 322, 8, 17, 529300) See for instance Gandhiji’s translation of verse 8 and Hoyland’s adaptation of it (p.
('50', 322, 8, 18, 529386) The version reproduced here is taken from a photostat of the original work in Gandhiji’s hand (C. W. 4903).
('50', 322, 8, 19, 529494) 2 Note by Gandhiji: “1st verse rewritten on 20 12 1930.” Gandhiji first wrote it on May 6, again on November 20 and then finally on this date.

('50', 407, 3, 7, 677352) It should be clearly understood that the mere practice of asanas and the like can never take us to the goal of even mindedness.
('50', 407, 3, 8, 677480) Asanas and pranayama may be of some slight help in steadying the mind and making it single purposed, provided that they are practised to that end.
('50', 407, 3, 9, 677627) Otherwise they are no better than other methods of physical training.
('50', 407, 3, 10, 677697) They are very useful indeed as physical exercise and I believe that this type of exercise is good for the soul, and may be performed from a bodily standpoint.
('50', 407, 3, 11, 677856) But I have observed that these practices do only harm when indulged in for the acquisition of supernormal powers (siddhi) and the performance of miracles.
('50', 407, 3, 12, 678011) This chapter should be studied as a summary of the teaching in the preceding three chapters.
('50', 407, 3, 13, 678104) It cheers us up in our spiritual struggle.
('50', 407, 3, 14, 678147) We should never be down hearted and give up the endeavour to reach evenness of temper.

('50', 411, 3, 21, 684412) 465. LETTER TO KASHINATH TRIVEDI YERAVDA MANDIR, December 18, 1930
('50', 411, 4, 22, 684479) KASHINATH, A person without art is like a beast.
('50', 411, 4, 23, 684528) But how will you define art?
('50', 411, 4, 24, 684557) Art is “skill in work”.
('50', 411, 4, 25, 684581) The yoga of the third chapter of the Gita is perfect art.
