('50', 422, 1, 2, 701509) 484. LETTER TO GANGABEHN VAIDYA
('50', 422, 2, 3, 701541) December 22, 1930
('50', 422, 3, 4, 701559) GANGABEHN (SENIOR), It no doubt puts a very heavy responsibility on us when parents of grown up girls entrust them to us.
('50', 422, 3, 5, 701681) God will help us to bear it.
('50', 422, 3, 6, 701710) When, however, you feel in a particular case that the responsibility will be beyond your strength, plainly refuse to accept it.
('50', 422, 3, 7, 701838) Sent away any girl who refuses to submit to your discipline.
('50', 422, 3, 8, 701899) Explain the position clearly to the parents and the girl before you accept her.
('50', 422, 3, 9, 701979) If we do not take such steps of practical wisdom, God will not help us.
('50', 422, 3, 10, 702051) He never helps the timid, the lethargic and those who are not vigilant.
('50', 422, 3, 11, 702123) Have any facilities you require, but safeguard your health.
('50', 422, 3, 12, 702183) If you think that tea and coffee are essential for it, take either without the slightest hesitation or without feeling ashamed about doing so.
('50', 422, 3, 13, 702326) Giving up tea or coffee is not at present the purpose of your sadhana; that purpose is the service of those among the inmates of the Ashram who suffer.
('50', 422, 3, 14, 702478) I cannot think of one single remedy which will help Madhu and all others in the Ashram who suffer from constipation.
('50', 422, 3, 15, 702595) I will tell you how I overcame it in my case.
('50', 422, 3, 16, 702641) For three or four days, I ate only cooked greens like tanka.
('50', 422, 3, 17, 702702) That completely restored my bowel movement.
('50', 422, 3, 18, 702746) Then I added almonds to the diet.
('50', 422, 3, 19, 702780) You do not need them for the people there.
('50', 422, 3, 20, 702823) Perhaps you will not get even greens.
('50', 422, 3, 21, 702861) But you can certainly get onions.
('50', 422, 3, 22, 702895) If those who suffer from constipation eat boiled onions, that, too, will probably help them.
('50', 422, 3, 23, 702988) If you can get tomatoes, you may mix them with onions.
('50', 422, 3, 24, 703043) If simple boiled onions do not taste well, even with the addition of salt, and if tomatoes are not available, they may use kokum.
('50', 422, 3, 25, 703173) The persons may try shirshasan.
('50', 422, 3, 26, 703205) It has helped people to overcome constipation from which they had suffered many years.
('50', 422, 3, 27, 703292) The asana should be done only on an empty stomach.
('50', 422, 3, 28, 703343) It is quite easy to do.
('50', 422, 3, 29, 703367) The skirt should be tucked up behind and one should stand on one’s head, supporting the body against a wall.
('50', 422, 3, 30, 703476) After some practice the support of the wall will not be necessary.
('50', 422, 3, 31, 703543) The head should be supported by the palms joined together.
('50', 422, 3, 32, 703602) I suppose you know that these days I eat the rotlas of jowar and bajra, and vegetables, served to prisoners in jail.
('50', 422, 3, 33, 703719) The vegetables for me have to be cooked separately, because those cooked
('50', 423, 0, 1, 703792) 424 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('50', 423, 1, 2, 703834) for other prisoners contain spices.
('50', 423, 1, 3, 703870) I continue to eat dates.
('50', 423, 1, 4, 703895) In place of milk I take four tolas of almonds.
('50', 423, 1, 5, 703942) I keep fairly good health.
('50', 423, 1, 6, 703969) If I do not keep it up, I will resume milk.

('50', 423, 3, 8, 704101) 485. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK YERAVDA MANDIR, December 22, 1930
('50', 423, 4, 9, 704167) PREMA, I got your letter full of information.
('50', 423, 4, 10, 704213) Both the meanings of nij anamagrahi 1 are good.
('50', 423, 4, 11, 704261) The meaning suggested by Narandas may suit Gujarati better, but the one suggested by you is not altogether in appropriate.
('50', 423, 4, 12, 704384) I imagine that you yourself are a little girl and reply to your question about prayer.
('50', 423, 4, 13, 704471) Just as we have parents who gave birth to us, so they had their parents who brought them into the world.
('50', 423, 4, 14, 704576) If we go further and further back like this, He whom we can conceive as the Father of all is God.
('50', 423, 4, 15, 704674) It is because He is that that we also call Him the Creator.
('50', 423, 4, 16, 704734) As our parents often come to know what we want without our telling them, so does God know our wishes.
('50', 423, 4, 17, 704836) If our human parents have this power to know what we want, the Creator of all must have infinitely greater power to know our heart.
('50', 423, 4, 18, 704968) That is why we also think of God as Antaryami, the Dweller within.
('50', 423, 4, 19, 705035) It is not necessary that we should be able to see Him.
('50', 423, 4, 20, 705090) We have never seen a good many of our relations.
('50', 423, 4, 21, 705139) Somebody’s parents may have gone away to a foreign country or died while he or she was a child, but such a man or woman trusts other people and believes that the parents live or lived.
('50', 423, 4, 22, 705324) Similarly, we should trust the testimony of saints about the existence of God and believe that the Antaryami does exist.
('50', 423, 4, 23, 705445) If that is so, it is easy to understand why we should sing bhajans to Him and pray to Him.
('50', 423, 4, 24, 705536) If we are good children, we bow to our parents, prostrating ourselves before them, the first thing in the morning after leaving bed and the last thing at night when going to bed.
('50', 423, 4, 25, 705715) We should do the same to God.
('50', 423, 4, 26, 705745) And as we tell our parents what we desire, so we should tell God.
('50', 423, 4, 27, 705811) This should be enough for today.
('50', 423, 4, 28, 705844) If you do not understand anything in this, do not hesitate to question me.

('50', 424, 8, 15, 706801) LILAVATI, You are being really tested.
('50', 424, 8, 16, 706840) See that you do not fail in the test.
('50', 424, 8, 17, 706878) One preserves one’s self respect better by giving up the very desire for being respected.
('50', 424, 8, 18, 706968) You will not get another Gangabehn who will look after you like a mother as she does.

('50', 424, 8, 22, 707169) Anyone who wishes to serve must learn to act as a member of an organization.
('50', 424, 8, 23, 707246) To do this means to obey somebody’s authority.
('50', 424, 8, 24, 707293) One’s superior has his or her superior too.
('50', 424, 8, 25, 707337) Think over the verses of Chapter XII of the Gita.
('50', 424, 8, 26, 707387) One of them says that a devotee and lover of God is equally indifferent to respect and disrespect, to praise and censure, and holds friend and foe in equal regard.
('50', 424, 8, 27, 707551) Let this be true about you.
('50', 424, 8, 28, 707579) Do not feel it a burden to write to me.

('50', 425, 6, 16, 708410) 489. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('50', 425, 7, 17, 708441) Thursday Morning, December 18/23, 1930
('50', 425, 8, 18, 708480) NARANDAS, I got your packet yesterday evening.
('50', 425, 8, 19, 708527) The letters to the Ashram which I handed in this time, that is, on Tuesday last, should reach you on Thursday, that is, today.
('50', 425, 8, 20, 708654) I suggested to the official here to post them immediately, if possible, and he told me afterwards that this week’s letters were posted on Tuesday itself.
('50', 425, 8, 21, 708808) I welcome your long letters, but I shall not be happy if you take special trouble to make them long.
('50', 425, 8, 22, 708909) I can understand what a burden you are carrying.
('50', 425, 8, 23, 708958) I did not want an explanation in regard to Keshu.
('50', 425, 8, 24, 709008) But I can understand your having given it so that you could your pour out your heart and satisfy yourself.
('50', 425, 8, 25, 709115) I had a postcard from Surajbhan, in which he says that he would be happy if Yashodadevi was called to the Ashram.
('50', 425, 8, 26, 709229) She lives with the family of Lala Dunichand, a lawyer, in Ambala.
('50', 425, 8, 27, 709295) Write to him.
('50', 425, 8, 28, 709309) The Ratilal episode is both happy and painful.
('50', 425, 8, 29, 709356) His foolishness is painful, but the display of humanity by the merchant, who returned the diamond, and by Gopi, who returned the money, makes one
('50', 426, 0, 1, 709502) VOL.50 : 23 AUGUST, 1930 5 JANUARY, 1932 427
('50', 426, 1, 2, 709547) In my eyes, their subsequent conduct wipes out their initial guilt.
('50', 426, 1, 3, 709615) Champa, of course, has always been foolish.
('50', 426, 1, 4, 709659) She listens to no persuasion and re mains fond of diamonds and other jewels, and loses money in conse quence.
('50', 426, 1, 5, 709769) Ratilal must have returned.
('50', 426, 1, 6, 709797) Even if he has not returned, that will not worry me.
('50', 426, 1, 7, 709850) God always saves him.
('50', 426, 1, 8, 709872) But this is what life is.
('50', 426, 1, 9, 709898) We pass our time in undoing the consequences of one another’s error.
('50', 426, 1, 10, 709967) For those who can remain unattached while doing this, their labour is not wasted.
('50', 426, 1, 11, 710049) To them it is a spiritual striving and they realize God through it.
('50', 426, 1, 12, 710117) I had an experience of this yesterday when I saw God in a worm and a weevil.
('50', 426, 1, 13, 710194) You are wrong if you think that you know Pyarelal fully.
('50', 426, 1, 14, 710251) Being a poet, he is bound to be dreaming always.
('50', 426, 1, 15, 710300) I asked him to remove a worm from the dates.
('50', 426, 1, 16, 710345) He should have put it in a safe corner, but, instead of thinking about his duty, he was thinking of something else, God knows what, and he put the worm in the wash basin.
('50', 426, 1, 17, 710516) The weevil, too, was dropped into the same.
('50', 426, 1, 18, 710560) If now I washed my hands or face in the basin, I would be the cause of the death of both.
('50', 426, 1, 19, 710650) I therefore, decided not to wash in it.
('50', 426, 1, 20, 710690) But when, after I had finished my work, I got ready to wash my hands, I did not see the worm and the weevil in the basin.
('50', 426, 1, 21, 710812) They had slowly moved away.
('50', 426, 1, 22, 710840) I look upon this experience as seeing God in the two worms.
('50', 426, 1, 23, 710900) An atheist or a rationalist would describe the incident as mere accident.
('50', 426, 1, 24, 710974) It was an accident, no doubt, but seeing God is also an accident.
('50', 426, 1, 25, 711040) If we but understand the truth, we would see Him every day; otherwise our whole life would pass without our seeing Him.
('50', 426, 1, 26, 711160) But I will not dwell further on this.
('50', 426, 1, 27, 711198) I wanted to note this incident in the diary yes terday, but, in my preoccupation with other work I wrote in it only about the daily sacrificial work and forgot to note this.
('50', 426, 1, 28, 711372) While writing about the merchant and Gopi, I remembered this holy experience and have shared it with you.
('50', 426, 1, 29, 711478) I learnt much else, too, from it yesterday.
('50', 426, 1, 30, 711522) God alone knows whether I shall be able to digest all that.
('50', 426, 1, 31, 711582) I will now answer your question here.
('50', 426, 1, 32, 711620) As we reflect deeper and remain peaceful, the meaning of ahimsa and truth becomes clearer.
('50', 426, 1, 33, 711711) I even realize the supreme utility of these two.
('50', 426, 1, 34, 711760) I believe we realize God in the degree to which we practise them.
('50', 426, 1, 35, 711826) I am gett ing more convinced than ever in my view that seeing God except through truth and ahimsa is an impossibility.
('50', 426, 1, 36, 711945) How can members of a group practise ahimsa towards one another?
('50', 426, 1, 37, 712009) They can do so by displaying generosity towards co workers and their faults and everyone regarding his own faults with strictness.
('50', 426, 1, 38, 712140) Anyone who observes the faults of others believes, whether he is conscious of the fact or not, that he does not have the same
('50', 427, 0, 1, 712266) 428 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('50', 427, 1, 2, 712308) faults.
('50', 427, 1, 3, 712316) This gives rise to pride.
('50', 427, 1, 4, 712342) The true rule is that one should oneself observe all rules strictly and tolerate others who seem slack in observing them.
('50', 427, 1, 5, 712464) This is not kindness but strict justice.
('50', 427, 1, 6, 712505) Do we really know what effort is made by a person in observing a rule even as slackly as he does?
('50', 427, 1, 7, 712603) If our seeming strictness in observing rules comes naturally to us, what is the value of that strictness?
('50', 427, 1, 8, 712709) Is it any cause for wonder if a man like Bhima can lift a weight of four pounds with the utmost ease?
('50', 427, 1, 9, 712811) A girl, however, might slip down while trying to lift one pound; what would we think of that Bhima if he laughed at her then?
('50', 427, 1, 10, 712937) Really speaking, the effort of that girl to lift one pound is of much greater value than Bhima’s lifting the weight of four pounds.
('50', 427, 1, 11, 713069) If Bhima had not lifted that weight, somebody else as strong would have lifted it; but by her effort to lift one pound that girl taught the world a lesson in doing one’s duty and earned God’s grace.
('50', 427, 1, 12, 713268) Our dharma therefore does not lie in criticizing others and thereby commiting violence; it lies in becoming more vigilant ourselves.
('50', 427, 1, 13, 713401) If a strong bullock is yoked with one seemingly or really weak, the former’s duty is to do more work and make up for the deficiency of the latter.
('50', 427, 1, 14, 713548) The driver goads it to labour harder.
('50', 427, 1, 15, 713586) If the strong bullock does not do the work expected of it, it is looked upon as a shirker; it is selfish and has no pity on the other one.
('50', 427, 1, 16, 713725) Let us never be shirkers.
('50', 427, 1, 17, 713751) Let us always do our duty.
('50', 427, 1, 18, 713778) God will judge us and our co workers.
('50', 427, 1, 19, 713816) He can see into the hearts of all.
('50', 427, 1, 20, 713851) We scarcely can see into our own.
('50', 427, 1, 21, 713885) We easily learn this if we strive sincerely to cultivate ahimsa.
('50', 427, 1, 22, 713950) Through the pursuit of truth, we know the measure of purity in our motives.
('50', 427, 1, 23, 714026) It increases our vigilance in regard to the smallest social duties and to our daily work.
('50', 427, 1, 24, 714116) If we strive for truth, we would not be content merely to attend prayers but would try to concentrate our attention on them.
('50', 427, 1, 25, 714241) We would try to follow the songs and the dis courses, be punctual in attending the prayers and respond to them as to a fresh experience every day.
('50', 427, 1, 26, 714388) The freshness does not consist in the variety of bhajans or other recitations, but should result from the increasing purity of our heart.
('50', 427, 1, 27, 714526) We should grow daily more contented and feel greater peace of mind.
('50', 427, 1, 28, 714594) If we do not have this experience, the fault will lie not with the quality of the prayers but with the element of untruth fulness in us.
('50', 427, 1, 29, 714731) If we attend the prayers with sincere devotion to truth, we would experience nothing but peace.
('50', 427, 1, 30, 714827) The faithful who visit temples do not observe the lack of cleanliness in them, or pay attention to the hypocrisy of the priest.
('50', 427, 1, 31, 714955) They do not see the image as a stone.
('50', 427, 1, 32, 714993) They experience peace in the midst of noise and return from
('50', 428, 0, 1, 715053) VOL.50 : 23 AUGUST, 1930 5 JANUARY, 1932 429
('50', 428, 1, 2, 715098) the temples purified in heart.
('50', 428, 1, 3, 715129) A person like me who feels suffocated by the noise there and sees the image only as a piece of stone should never visit a temple.
('50', 428, 1, 4, 715259) God appears to us in the form in which we worship Him.
('50', 428, 1, 5, 715314) For He is not outside of us.
('50', 428, 1, 6, 715343) He is in the hearts of us all.
('50', 428, 1, 7, 715374) If we understand this truth, our simplest and smallest actions would shed lustre on us and help us to see God.

('50', 448, 1, 2, 752439) 519. A LETTER
('50', 448, 2, 3, 752453) YERAVDA MANDIR, December 31, 1930
('50', 448, 3, 4, 752487) CHI., It is possible that, from an academic standpoint, my interpretation of the phrase “
('50', 448, 4, 5, 752577) <image: None, width: 15, height: 12, bpc: 1>
('50', 448, 5, 6, 752622) <image: None, width: 18, height: 12, bpc: 1>
('50', 448, 6, 7, 752667) <image: None, width: 24, height: 12, bpc: 1>
('50', 448, 7, 8, 752712) <image: None, width: 9, height: 12, bpc: 1>
('50', 448, 8, 9, 752756) is of no value.
('50', 448, 8, 10, 752772) But I think it is possible to interpret it to refer both to the self and the body.
('50', 448, 8, 11, 752855) The self unclouded by ignorance knows neither birth nor death.
('50', 448, 8, 12, 752918) However, one who believes that it dies must believe also that it is born again.
('50', 448, 8, 13, 752998) For, nothing in this world suffers total destruction, not even physical body.
('50', 448, 8, 14, 753076) It ceases to exist in one form and takes another.
('50', 448, 8, 15, 753126) It goes on ever changing its form.
('50', 448, 8, 16, 753161) After the body has been reduced to ashes it will not remain unchanged for ever in the form of atoms, for the atoms will change too.
('50', 448, 8, 17, 753293) “When turned into ornaments, gold acquires different names and forms but it, ever remains gold.” Does this appeal to your reason in any way?
('50', 448, 8, 18, 753434) As Vinoba’s style is very lively, he wins our interest.
('50', 448, 8, 19, 753490) However, I have come to the conclusion that it is possible to put more than one interpretation on the words of the Gita and that all of them may be right.
('50', 448, 8, 20, 753645) The central meaning would remain the same, and consistent with it there may be as many interpretations as one may wish, which together, like the numerous instruments in an orchestra, produce a beautiful symphony.
('50', 448, 8, 21, 753858) As regards “is seated,” “sits” and “walks,” it is possible to draw out three distinct meaning.
('50', 448, 8, 22, 753953) But the Gita is not a technical or scientific work composed with such precision.
('50', 448, 8, 23, 754034) It abounds in repetitions, and there is looseness of expression too.
('50', 448, 8, 24, 754103) This is not a defect, but it is there.
('50', 448, 8, 25, 754142) These days I have been spinning on the takli at least 100 rounds a day.
('50', 448, 8, 26, 754214) I have given up the iron takli, after having tried very hard to spin well on it, and now I am back to the bamboo takli.
('50', 448, 8, 27, 754334) I feel a little better with it.
('50', 448, 8, 28, 754366) The speed has risen to 75 per hour.
('50', 448, 8, 29, 754402) It will go up still.
('50', 448, 8, 30, 754423) After I have mastered the bamboo takli fully, I will return to the iron one.
('50', 448, 9, 31, 754500) Blessings from BAPU

('50', 449, 3, 4, 754669) BHAGWANJI, You have construed the answers to your questions all right.

('50', 449, 3, 6, 754776) There is no end to conflicts of loyalties and to miseries.

('50', 456, 7, 14, 767358) The idea is that the universe is not real in the sense of being permanent, it is neither a thing to be hankered after nor feared because it is supposed to be God’s creation.

('50', 460, 4, 8, 773211) 540. LETTER TO VASUMATI PANDIT YERAVDA MANDIR, Sunday Morning, January 4, 1931
('50', 460, 5, 9, 773290) VASUMATI, I am writing this immediately after morning prayers.
('50', 460, 5, 10, 773353) Taste ultimately is a matter of the palate and the mind.
('50', 460, 5, 11, 773410) Our vow is that we will not gratify the craving of the palate.
('50', 460, 5, 12, 773473) The latter will always feel and recognize the taste of every food.
('50', 460, 5, 13, 773540) But to gratify the craving of the palate means to eat food which it likes and avoid food which it dislikes.
('50', 460, 5, 14, 773648) We may certainly eat whatever food the body requires, but only at the time when and in the quantity which the body requires, and it does not matter then if it gives us pleasure.
('50', 460, 5, 15, 773826) When Mahavir has conquered the palate, he will gladly accept what is for his good.
('50', 460, 5, 16, 773909) Ordinarily, a man does not care for his spiritual good and does what will give him pleasure for the time being even if that is likely to harm him spiritually.
('50', 460, 5, 17, 774068) Hence the attitude, that one should accept whatever is offered to one at any time, is not the right one for a spiritual seeker.
('50', 460, 5, 18, 774196) We do not know from experience how a person who has attained perfection acts, and need not concern ourselves with the question.
('50', 460, 5, 19, 774324) Let us wait till we have attained perfection.
('50', 460, 5, 20, 774370) The question then will not arise at all.
('50', 460, 5, 21, 774411) It this does not answer all your question, ask me again.
('50', 460, 5, 22, 774468) It is a good sign that we notice even our small defects.
('50', 460, 5, 23, 774525) We ought to know whether we are striving to overcome them.
('50', 460, 5, 24, 774584) If I see that I have pride in me and if I am a spiritual seeker, I am bound to make an effort to get rid of it.
('50', 460, 5, 25, 774696) I shall not feel easy in mind till I have got rid of it.
('50', 460, 5, 26, 774753) If there is a snake in the house, we shall not feel easy in mind till we have caught and removed it.
('50', 460, 5, 27, 774854) If asked, we can certainly say whether
('50', 461, 0, 1, 774893) 462 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('50', 461, 1, 2, 774935) we are trying to remove it.
('50', 461, 1, 3, 774963) This is also true about snakes and other such poisonous creatures in our hearts.
('50', 461, 1, 4, 775044) I am glad that your ear is now all right.
('50', 461, 2, 5, 775086) Blessings from BAPU From a photostat of the Gujarati: S.N.9316.

('50', 467, 11, 23, 785395) 553. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK
('50', 467, 12, 24, 785427) January 5, 1931
('50', 467, 14, 25, 785443) I have your letter.
('50', 467, 14, 26, 785463) In my opinion, the view of Vivekananda and Dhurandhar is one sided.
('50', 467, 14, 27, 785531) One should feel in the heart what one says.
('50', 467, 14, 28, 785575) Surdas, Tulsidas and other bhaktas have described themselves as cunnings, lustful, etc.
('50', 467, 14, 29, 785663) In doing so, they were not merely using the
('50', 468, 0, 1, 785707) VOL 50 : 23 AUGUST, 1930 5 JANUARY, 1931 469
('50', 468, 1, 2, 785752) language of modesty, but speaking from the heart.
('50', 468, 1, 3, 785802) The truth is that we feel both ways.
('50', 468, 1, 4, 785839) In an enlightened state, we know ourselves to be Brahman, but in the ignorant state we feel meek and humble before that Merciful One.
('50', 468, 1, 5, 785973) He who does not feel so but knows himself as the perfect Brahman may not sing bhajans praying for God’s mercy.
('50', 468, 1, 6, 786084) You will not come across one such person in millions.
('50', 468, 1, 7, 786138) To realize one’s smallness is the beginning of being great.
('50', 468, 1, 8, 786198) The drop of sea water which has become separated from the sea would dry up if it thought that it was still the sea.
('50', 468, 1, 9, 786314) If it admitted to itself that it was no more than a drop, it would flow towards the sea, merge in it and become one with it.
('50', 468, 1, 10, 786439) “Culture” means refinement of feelings and “education” means knowledge of literature.
('50', 468, 1, 11, 786525) Education is a means and culture is the end.
('50', 468, 1, 12, 786570) The latter is possible even without education.
('50', 468, 1, 13, 786617) For instance, if a child is brought up in a truly cultured family, it will unconsciously imbibe culture from its environment.
('50', 468, 1, 14, 786743) In our country at any rate, present day education and culture have no connection with each other.
('50', 468, 1, 15, 786841) If the educated still retain some culture, that is in spite of their education.
('50', 468, 1, 16, 786921) This fact shows that the roots of our culture are deep.
('50', 468, 1, 17, 786977) My blessings and compliments to Prasannabehn.
('50', 468, 1, 18, 787023) I should like her to draw her husband also to the Ashram.
('50', 468, 1, 19, 787081) You seem to be running a competition in the opposite direction with Narandas with regard to weight.
('50', 468, 1, 20, 787181) It is good.
('50', 468, 1, 21, 787193) You can afford to put on some more weight, and Narandas to lose some.
('50', 468, 1, 22, 787263) I like the translation of Gitabodh which Dhurandhar is making.
('50', 468, 1, 23, 787326) Blessings from BAPU

('50', 469, 0, 1, 787391) 470 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('50', 469, 1, 2, 787433) APPENDICES
('50', 469, 2, 3, 787444) APPENDIX I
('50', 469, 3, 4, 787455) VICEROY'S LETTER TO SIR T. B. SAPRU 1
('50', 469, 4, 5, 787493) VICEREGAL LODGE, SIMLA, August 28, 1930
('50', 469, 5, 6, 787533) DEAR SIR TEJ BAHADUR,
('50', 469, 6, 7, 787555) I have to thank you for informing me of the results of the conversations held by Mr. Jayakar and yourself with the Congress leaders now in prison and for sending me copies of their joint letter of the 15th August and of your reply thereto.
('50', 469, 6, 8, 787795) I should wish you and Mr. Jayakar both to know how great has been my appreciation of the spirit in which you have pursued your self imposed public spirited task of endeavouring to assist in the restoration of normal conditions in India.
('50', 469, 6, 9, 788032) It is worth recalling the conditions under which you entered upon your undertaking.
('50', 469, 6, 10, 788116) In my letter of 16th July I assured you that it was the earnest desire of myself, my Government and I had no doubt also of His Majesty's Government, to do everything we could to assist the people of India to obtain as large degree of management of their own affairs as could be shown to be consistent with the making of provision for those matters in regard to which they were not at present in a position to assumeresponsibility.
('50', 469, 6, 11, 788547) It would be among the functions of the Conference to examine in the light of all the material available what those matters might be and what provision might be made for them.
('50', 469, 6, 12, 788722) I had previously made two other points plain in my speech to the Legislature on the 9th July.
('50', 469, 6, 13, 788816) The first is that those attending the Conference would have the unfettered right of examining the whole constitutional problem in all its bearing.
('50', 469, 6, 14, 788963) Secondly, that any agreement at which the Conference was able to arrive would form the basis of the proposals which His Majesty's Government would later submit to Parliament.
('50', 469, 6, 15, 789138) I fear as you will no doubt recognize that the task you had voluntarily undertaken has not been assisted by the letter you have received from the Congress leaders.
('50', 469, 6, 16, 789302) In view both of the general tone by which that letter is inspired and of its contents, as also of its blank refusal to recognize the grave injury to which the country has been subjected by the Congress policy, not the least in the economic field, I do not think any useful purpose would be served by my attempting to deal in detail with the suggestions there made and I must frankly say I regard discussion on the basis of the proposals contained in the letter as impossible.
('50', 469, 6, 17, 789778) I hope if you desire to see the Congress leaders again you will make this plain.
('50', 469, 7, 18, 789859) There is one further comment I must make upon the last paragraph of your reply to them dated 16th August.
('50', 469, 7, 19, 789965) When we discussed these matters, I said if the Civil
('50', 469, 8, 20, 790018) 1 Vide “Statement to T. B. Sapru and M. R. Jayakar”, 5 9 1930
('50', 470, 0, 1, 790080) VOL.50 : 23 AUGUST, 1930 5 JANUARY, 1931 471
('50', 470, 1, 2, 790125) Disobedience Movement was in fact abandoned, I should not desire to continue the Ordinances (apart from those connected with the Lahore Conspiracy Case and Chittagong) necessitated by the situation which EX HYPOTHESI would no longer exist.
('50', 470, 1, 3, 790365) But I was careful to make it plain that I was unable to give any assurance, if and when the Civil Disobedience Movement ceases, that local Governments would find it possible to release all persons convicted or under trial for offences in connection with the movement not involving violence, and that while I should wish to see a generous policy pursued in the matter, the utmost that I could promise would be to [ask] all the local Governments to consider with sympathy all the cases individually on their merits.
('50', 470, 2, 4, 790879) Upon the point of your reference to the representation of the Congress at the Conference in the event of their abandoning the Civil Disobedience Movement and desiring to attend, my recollection is you explained that the demand of the Congress was not for predominant, in the sense of majority, representation at the Conference and that I expressed the view that I should anticipate little difficulty in recommending to His Majesty's Government to secure that the Congress should be adequately represented.
('50', 470, 2, 5, 791385) I added that if events so developed, I should be ready to receive a panel of names from the leaders of the Congress Party of those whom they would regard as suitable representatives.
('50', 470, 2, 6, 791568) I feel that you and Mr. Jayakar would desire to be clearly informed of the position of myself and my Government as it may be desirable that the letters should be published at an early date in order that the public may be fullyinformed of the circumstances,in which your efforts have failed to produce the result you hoped and they so certain]y deserved.
('50', 470, 3, 7, 791922) Yours sincerely, IRWIN
('50', 470, 4, 8, 791945) The Hindu, 5 9 1930
('50', 470, 5, 9, 791965) APPENDIX II
('50', 470, 6, 10, 791977) NOTES OF CONVERSATIONS WITH VICEROY 1
('50', 470, 7, 11, 792015) (a) On the constitutional question, the position would be as stated in the four fundamental points in para 2 of the Viceroy's letter to us of 28th August.
('50', 470, 8, 12, 792170) (b) With reference to the question whether Mr. Gandhi would be allowed to raise at the Round Table Conference the question of India's right to secede from the Empire at will, the position was as follows: “As the Viceroy has stated in his said letter to us, the Conference was a free conference.
('50', 470, 8, 13, 792465) Therefore, anyone could raise any points he liked, but the Viceroy thought it would be very unwise for Mr. Gandhi to raise this question now.
('50', 470, 8, 14, 792607) If, however, he faced the Government of India with such a question, the Viceroy would say the Government were not prepared to treat it as an
('50', 470, 9, 15, 792748) 1 Held at Simla with Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru and M. R. Jayakar between August 21 and 28. Vide also 1st footnote of “Statement to T. B. Sapru and M. R. Jayakar”, 5 9 1930
('50', 471, 0, 1, 792916) 472 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('50', 471, 1, 2, 792958) open question.
('50', 471, 1, 3, 792973) If, in spite of this, Mr. Gandhi desired to raise the question, the Government would inform the Secretary of State of his intention to do so at the Round Table Conference.”
('50', 471, 2, 4, 793146) (c) As regards the right to raise the question at the Round Table Conference of India's liability to certain financial burdens and to get them examined by an independent Tribunal, the position was that the Viceroy could not entertain any proposition amounting to total repudiation of all debts, but it would be open to anyone to raise, at the Round Table Conference, any question as to any financial liability of India and to call for its examination.
('50', 471, 3, 5, 793598) (d) As regards the granting of relief against the Salt Act, the position of the Viceroy was that (1) the Salt Tax was going to be provincialized if the recommendation of the Simon Commission in that behalf was accepted, and (2) there has been already great loss of revenue and therefore the Government would not like to forgo this source, but if the Legislature was persuaded to repeal the Salt Act and if any proposal was put forward to make good the loss of revenue occasioned by such repeal, the Viceroy and his Government would consider the question on its merits.
('50', 471, 3, 6, 794167) It was not, however, possible for the Viceroy to condone open breaches of the Salt Act so long as it was law.
('50', 471, 3, 7, 794277) When goodwill and peace were restored and, if Indian leaders desired to discuss with H. E. the Viceroy and his Government how best economic relief couldbe given to the poorer classes on his behalf, the Viceroy would be glad to call a small conference of Indian leaders.
('50', 471, 4, 8, 794547) (e) With reference to picketing, the position was that if picketing amounted to nuisance to any class of people or was coupled with molestation or intimidation or the use of force, the Viceroy reserved to the Government the right of taking such action as the law allowed or taking of such legal powers as might be necessary to meet any emergency that might arise.
('50', 471, 4, 9, 794911) Subject to the above when peace was established the Ordinance against picketing would be withdrawn.
('50', 471, 5, 10, 795011) (f) With regard to the re employment of the officers who resigned or had been dismissed during the Civil Disobedience campaign, the position was that this matter was primarily a question for the discretion of local Governments.
('50', 471, 5, 11, 795239) Subject however to there being vacancies and as long as it did not involve dismissing men who had proved loyal, the local Government would be expected to re employ men who had thrown up their appointments in a fit of excitement or who had been swept off their feet.
('50', 471, 6, 12, 795505) (g) As for the restoration of printing presses confiscated under the Press Ordinance, there would be no difficulty.
('50', 471, 7, 13, 795621) (h) As regards the restoration of fines and properties confiscated under the Revenue Law, that required closer definition.
('50', 471, 7, 14, 795744) As to the properties confiscated or sold
('50', 472, 0, 1, 795785) VOL.50 : 23 AUGUST, 1930 5 JANUARY, 1931 473
('50', 472, 1, 2, 795830) under such law, there might be the rights of third parties involved.
('50', 472, 1, 3, 795899) As to refunding fines, there were difficulties.
('50', 472, 1, 4, 795947) In short, all that the Viceroy could say was that the local Government would exercise their discretion with justice and take all the circumstances into consideration and try to be as accommodating as they could.
('50', 472, 2, 5, 796159) (i) As to the release of prisoners, the Viceroy had already explained his views in his letter to us dated July 28th.
('50', 472, 3, 6, 796276) The Hindu, 5 9 1930
('50', 472, 4, 7, 796296) APPENDIX III
('50', 472, 5, 8, 796309) NOTE FROM NEHRUS1
('50', 472, 6, 9, 796327) NAINI CENTRAL PRISON, August 31, 1930
('50', 472, 7, 10, 796365) We have had further interviews with Mr. M. R. Jayakar and Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru yesterday and today, and have had the advantage of long talks with them.
('50', 472, 7, 11, 796518) They have given us a copy of the letter, dated August 23, addressed to them by His Excellency Lord Irwin.
('50', 472, 7, 12, 796624) In this letter, it is stated clearly that Lord Irwin regards discussion on the basis of the proposals contained in our joint letter of August 15 to Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru and Mr. Jayakar as impossible, andunder the circumstances, he rightly concludes their efforts have failed to produce any result.
('50', 472, 7, 13, 796923) This joint letter, as you know, was written after a full consideration by the signatories to it, and represented the utmost they were prepared to go in their individual capacities.
('50', 472, 7, 14, 797104) We stated there that no solution would be satisfactory unless it fulfilled certain vital conditions, and that a satisfactory declaration to that effect was made by the British Government.
('50', 472, 7, 15, 797292) If such a declaration was made, we would be prepared to recommend to the Working Committee the advisability of calling off Civil Disobedience, provided simultaneously certain steps indicated in our letter were taken by the British Government in India.
('50', 472, 8, 16, 797544) It was only after a satisfactory settlement of all these preliminaries, that the question of the composition of the proposed London Conference and of the Congress being represented at it could be decided.
('50', 472, 8, 17, 797749) Lord Irwin, in his letter, considers even a discussion on the basis of these proposals as impossible.
('50', 472, 8, 18, 797851) Under the circumstances, there is or can be no common ground between us.
('50', 472, 8, 19, 797924) Quite apart from the contents, the tone of the letter and the recent activities of the British Government in India clearly indicate that the Government has no desire for peace.
('50', 472, 8, 20, 798101) The proclamation of the Working Committee as an illegal body in the Delhi Province soon after a meeting of it was announced to be held there, and the subsequent arrest of most of its members can have that meaning and no other.
('50', 472, 8, 21, 798328) We have no complaint against these or other arrests or other activities of the Government, 'uncivilized' and 'barbarous' as we
('50', 472, 9, 22, 798455) 1 Vide 1st footnote of “Statement to T. B. Sapru and M. R. Jayakar”, 5 9 1930
('50', 473, 0, 1, 798533) 474 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('50', 473, 1, 2, 798575) consider some of these to be.
('50', 473, 1, 3, 798605) We welcome them.
('50', 473, 1, 4, 798622) But, we feel, we are justified in pointing out that a desire for peace and an aggressive attack on the very body, which is capable of giving peace and with which it is sought to treat, do not go well together.
('50', 473, 1, 5, 798832) The proscription of the Working Committee all over India and the attempt to prevent its meetings must necessarily mean that the national struggle must go on, whatever the consequences, and that there will be no possibility of peace, for those who may have some authority to represent the people of India will be spread out in British prisons all over India.
('50', 473, 2, 6, 799190) Lord Irwin's letter and the action taken by the British Government make it plain that the efforts of Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru and Mr. Jayakar have been in vain.
('50', 473, 2, 7, 799348) Indeed, the letter and some of the explanations that had been given to us take us back, in some respects, even from the position that was previously taken.
('50', 473, 2, 8, 799504) In view of the great HIATUS that exists between our position and Lord Irwin's, it is hardly necessary to go into details, but we should like to point out to you certain aspects of his letter.
('50', 473, 2, 9, 799696) The first part of the letter is practically a repetition of his speech to the Legislative Assembly and of the phrases used in his letter dated July 16, addressed to Mr. Jayakar and Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru.
('50', 473, 2, 10, 799900) As we pointed out in our joint letter, this phraseology is too vague for us to assess its value.
('50', 473, 2, 11, 799997) It may be made to mean anything or nothing.
('50', 473, 2, 12, 800041) In our joint letter, we have made it clear that a complete National Government responsible to the people of India, including control over the DefenceForces and economic control, must be recognized as India's immediate demand.
('50', 473, 2, 13, 800267) There is no question of what are usually called safeguards or any delay.
('50', 473, 2, 14, 800340) Adjustments there necessarily must be for the transference of power and in regard to these we stated that they were to be determined by India's chosen representatives.
('50', 473, 3, 15, 800508) As regards India's right of secession at will from the British Empire and her right to refer British claims and concessions to an independent tribunal all that we are told is that the Conference will be a free conference and any point can be raised there.
('50', 473, 3, 16, 800764) This is no advance on the previous statement made.
('50', 473, 3, 17, 800815) We are further told, however, that if the British Government in India were definitely faced with the possibility of the former question being raised, Lord Irwin would say they were not to treat it as an open question.
('50', 473, 3, 18, 801033) All they could do was to inform the Secretary of State of our intention to raise the question at the Conference.
('50', 473, 4, 19, 801146) As regards the other proposition, we are told that Lord Irwin could only entertain the idea of a few individual financial transactions being subjected for scrutiny.
('50', 473, 4, 20, 801311) While such scrutiny may take place in individual cases, its scope will have to extend to the whole field of British claims including, as we have stated, the so called Public Debt of India.
('50', 473, 4, 21, 801500) We consider both these questions as of vital importance and previous agreement in our joint letter seems to us essential.
('50', 473, 5, 22, 801622) Lord Irwin's reference to the release of prisoners is very restricted and unsatisfactory.
('50', 473, 5, 23, 801712) He is unable to give an assurance that all of the non violent civil disobedience prisoners even will be discharged.
('50', 473, 5, 24, 801828) All he proposes to do is to leave the matter in the hands of the Local Governments.
('50', 473, 5, 25, 801912) We are not prepared to trust in such a
('50', 474, 0, 1, 801951) VOL.50 : 23 AUGUST, 1930 5 JANUARY, 1931 475
('50', 474, 1, 2, 801996) matter to the generosity or sympathy of Local Governments or local officials but, apart from this, there is no reference in Lord Irwin's letter to other non violent prisoners.
('50', 474, 1, 3, 802172) There are a large number of Congressmen and others who were sent to prison for political offences prior to the Civil Disobedience Movement.
('50', 474, 1, 4, 802312) We might mention in this connection the Meerut Case prisoners who have already spent a year and a half as under trials.
('50', 474, 1, 5, 802432) We have made it clear in our joint letter that all these persons should be released.
('50', 474, 2, 6, 802517) Regarding the Bengal and the Lahore Case Ordinances we feel no exception
('50', 474, 3, 7, 802590) should be made in their favour as suggested by Lord Irwin.
('50', 474, 3, 8, 802649) We have not claimed
('50', 474, 4, 9, 802669) release for those political prisoners who may have been guilty of violence not
('50', 474, 5, 10, 802748) because we would not welcome their release but because we felt that as our movement
('50', 474, 6, 11, 802832) was strictly non violent, we would not confuse the issue.
('50', 474, 6, 12, 802890) But, the least we can do is
('50', 474, 7, 13, 802918) to press for ordinary trial for these fellow countrymen of ours and not by an
('50', 474, 8, 14, 802996) extraordinary court constituted by an Ordinance which denies them the right of
('50', 474, 9, 15, 803075) appeal and the ordinary privilege of accused.
('50', 474, 10, 16, 803121) Amazing events including the brutal assaults that have occurred even in open
('50', 474, 11, 17, 803198) court during the so called trial make it imperative that the ordinary procedureshould
('50', 474, 12, 18, 803284) be followed.
('50', 474, 12, 19, 803297) We understand that some of the accused in protest against the treatment
('50', 474, 13, 20, 803369) accorded to them have been on hunger strike for a long period and are now at death's
('50', 474, 14, 21, 803454) The Bengal Ordinance, we understand, has been replaced by an Act of the Bengal
('50', 474, 15, 22, 803533) Council.
('50', 474, 15, 23, 803542) We consider this Ordinance and any Act passed on it most objectionable,
('50', 474, 16, 24, 803614) and the fact that an unrepresentative body like the present Bengal Council has passed
('50', 474, 17, 25, 803700) it does not make it any the better.
('50', 474, 18, 26, 803736) As regards the further picketing of foreign cloth and liquor shops, we are told,
('50', 474, 19, 27, 803817) Lord Irwin is agreeable to the withdrawal of the Picketing Ordinance, but he states
('50', 474, 20, 28, 803901) that if he thinks it necessary, he will take fresh legal powers to combat picketing.
('50', 474, 21, 29, 803986) Thus, he informs us that he might re enact the Ordinance or do something in Simla to
('50', 474, 22, 30, 804071) it whenever he considers it necessary.
('50', 474, 22, 31, 804110) The reply regarding the Salt Act and certain
('50', 474, 23, 32, 804155) other matters referred to in our joint letter is also wholly unsatisfactory.
('50', 474, 23, 33, 804232) We need not
('50', 474, 24, 34, 804244) deal with it at any length here as you are an acknowledged expert on salt.
('50', 474, 24, 35, 804319) We would
('50', 474, 25, 36, 804328) only say we see no reason to modify our previous position as regards these matters.
('50', 474, 26, 37, 804412) Thus Lord Irwin has declined to agree to all the major propositions and many of the minor ones laid down in our joint letter.
('50', 474, 26, 38, 804538) The difference in his outlook and ours is very great, indeed fundamental.
('50', 474, 26, 39, 804612) We hope you will show this note to Mrs. Sarojini Naidu, Mr. Vallabhbhai Patel, Mr. Jairamdas Doulatram and in consultation with them give your reply to Mr. Jayakar and Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru.
('50', 474, 26, 40, 804803) We feel that the publication of the correspondence must no longer be delayed, and we are not justified in keeping
('50', 475, 0, 1, 804917) 476 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('50', 475, 1, 2, 804959) the public in the dark.
('50', 475, 1, 3, 804983) Even apart from the question of publication, we are requesting Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru and Mr. Jayakar to send copies of all correspondence and relevant papers to Chaudhri Khaliq Usman, the Acting President of the Indian National Congress.
('50', 475, 1, 4, 805221) We feel we ought to take no steps without immediate information being sent to the Working Committee, which happens to be functioning.
('50', 475, 1, 5, 805355) MOTILAL SYED MAHMUD JAWAHARLAL
('50', 475, 2, 6, 805386) The Hindu, 5 9 1930
